name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The first item is the debate on the report by Marco Affronte, on behalf of the Committee on Fisheries, on the proposal for an EU framework for the collection, management and use of data in the fisheries sector (COM (2015) 0294 - C8-0160 / 2015 - 2015 /0133 (COD)) (A8-0150 / 2016).

name: Marco AFFRONTE
text: speaker. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the collection of scientific data is essential for the implementation of the common fisheries policy, as it allows it to be based on the best scientific advice. The data is used to assess the state of fish stocks, the profitability of the various segments of the sector and the impact of fisheries and aquaculture on ecosystems. But the data are also needed to evaluate EU policies: fisheries management measures, financial and structural measures to support fisheries and culture, mitigation measures designed to reduce the negative effects of fishing on the ecosystem. We need scientific data to apply good rules and effective fisheries management policies and we need data to assess whether these policies work or need to be modified and improved. For this reason, a European Union framework for the collection and management of fisheries data was established in 2000 and became the Data Collection Framework (DCF) in 2008, which represented an important advance in development of a harmonized set of Union standards for the collection of biological, environmental, technical and socio-economic data on the fisheries, aquaculture and processing sectors. The common fisheries policy requires us to manage fishing activities taking into account their impact on the ecosystem. On this basis we must build a deeper and more complete knowledge of marine ecosystems, so as not to move blindly and not realize the consequences of our policies only after they appear, often in a negative way. This is particularly important in order to achieve Maximum Sustainable Yield (MSY) by 2020. Maximum Sustainable Yield is a relatively new and very important concept, but it is based on numerical values ​​that need to be established scientifically and based on data, studies and research. The Commission's proposal on this dossier was based on what already worked in the current data collection system, thus maintaining continuity but at the same time allowing for adaptation to the new requirements. What we have managed to achieve, thanks to the work we have done together with the shadow rapporteurs, with whom there has been great agreement on this report and great sharing especially in difficult moments of discussion with the Council, is an expanded scope in to understand the collection of data for the protection of the marine environment, i.e. data used to assess the impact of fishing on the marine ecosystem, including vulnerable marine areas and the most sensitive species and habitats. This, of course, together with the data necessary for the sustainable management of all commercially exploited species and in particular for the achievement of good ecological status by 2020. We have included the need to cover those so-called data deficient fisheries, ie without necessary current support of scientific knowledge; we also wanted these data to be available to everyone: institutions, researchers, environmental associations and anyone interested in studying and evaluating them. But we have also set tighter deadlines for Member States to respond to requests for data from end users and other stakeholders. We are moving in the direction of databases at the regional level, this is important because the data are collected on larger marine areas and in a standardized and harmonized way. We will also collect data on aquaculture, both on a biological and socio-economic level; we will collect data on recreational fishing, although in this case we were partially defeated because it was important to enter socio-economic data but we did not make it; we still have the environmental impact of fishing recreational.We have insisted that an adequate and comprehensive number of mandatory research campaigns at sea be achieved, to be established at Union level, and finally, following a long tug-of-war with the Council, we have achieved that most of thedata collection, in particular the list of which data and which categories of data to collect, is adopted through delegated acts.In this way we have defended the prerogatives of the European Parliament which must be able to evaluate and pronounce on such important acts.

name: Marco AFFRONTE
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, can I just say a few words on behalf of Commissioner Vella, who would very much have liked to have been here for this discussion, but who unfortunately could not travel. Data collection might seem a rather technical issue, but it is – as we have just heard – fundamental to work in this area. It has been said that if you do not measure it, you cannot manage it, and management of our fish stocks is of critical importance for the stocks themselves and for the livelihood of our fishing communities. The European Parliament and the Council recognised this at the time of the adoption of the common fisheries policy, making a common declaration calling on the Commission to fast-track the review of the data collection framework. The Commission delivered, and today I am happy to see that we have reached a political agreement on the new regulation, which can finally be adopted and published. This will enable the scientific institutions in Member States to start collecting the necessary data for all the new requirements of the CFP. This has been possible thanks to this House’s will to tackle efficiently such a technical subject. We can now move one step forward towards enhancing regional cooperation in data collection, which has been an important objective of the CFP reforms. The data collection framework is essential for the implementation of the CFP as it provides the basic data for scientific advice on fishing quotas and on impact assessments for the evolution of EU fisheries. The recast was focused on two main issues. First, to ensure delivery on CFP reform objectives, providing the scientific data necessary for sustainable fisheries and aquaculture, while protecting the marine ecosystem and reducing discards and, at the same time, achieving economic, social, unemployment benefits and food security. Second, to simplify the current system: collect only what is needed, remove overlaps and reduce the number of rules at EU level. Overall, as has been recognised, the current framework has proven to be fit for purpose, and therefore the basic principles will not change. EU multiannual programmes are agreed and adopted at EU level and then implemented by national work plans in which Member States divide tasks amongst themselves. Basic data storage will remain at Member State level, and Member States will remain responsible for ensuring that good quality data is available to end users such as the International Council for the Exploration of the Sea.  An important issue that was debated in the final stages between Parliament and Council was the adoption procedure for the multiannual programmes on data collection, which define the detailed data requirements, the list of scientific surveys at sea and thresholds for the obligation to collect data. We are satisfied with the final compromise, which splits up the multiannual programme in a delegated act for the data requirements and implementing acts for the thresholds and the list of surveys. Thank you to the rapporteur for his work on this and for the opportunity this morning to discuss this important subject.

name: Werner KUHN
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, Commissioner King! I would like to extend my warmest thanks to the rapporteur, Marco Affronte, who has done very constructive work on this. It was a good cooperation with the shadow reporters too. And we all agreed that collecting data from the fishing sector, but also from recreational fishing and aquaculture, is an important basis for assessing the current situation of fish stocks, i.e. the stocks. We are there and are making multi-year, multi-species plans for the Baltic Sea, we are now with the North Sea, continue to the west-east Atlantic and then afterwards also to the Mediterranean. And for this it is absolutely necessary that we have scientifically based data available. Everyone has to cooperate, all stakeholders who are, so to speak, involved in the system. The sector plays a very decisive and major role, i.e. professional fishing. She is of course obliged to document the data on her landed catch anyway and to give it to the responsible authorities. But we also want to tackle this in the area of ​​recreational fishing. This is increasingly a sector that we are grappling with because, firstly, it is of great economic importance, but secondly, of course, the fishing mortality of different fish species also plays a very decisive role. It is therefore necessary that we also collect data there. In the area of ​​aquaculture, I would like to say that this is of course also very important for supplying the population with fish and fish products. Europe is the largest import market in the world. We can only realize about a third with our own resources and supply our population, our customers. Everything else is imports. That is why we pay particular attention to the area of ​​aquaculture, the circular economy. But of course we also need data for this. Right, Commissioner, you mentioned that: it is necessary for us to be able to enforce the common fisheries policy, the basic regulation, even more precisely in the future. The International Council for the Exploration of the Sea then of course also needs data. You can certainly also collect these alone with your research vessels, but not to the same extent as if we include the three sectors - that is, commercial fishing, which brings quoted catches, but also unquoted catches, recreational fishing, which ultimately also provide their data must, and in aquaculture it should be in a special way the marine area, that is, aquaculture that takes place in the coastal areas, that we have the data there to also get feedback on what effect it actually has on the ecosystem. The interaction between the individual species also plays a role. In this respect, I have to say, we have achieved good results and, as a Parliament, have prevailed over the Council to such an extent that the delegated acts are clearly defined: Who has to do what? It is clearly clear that the mandatory data collection applies to the open sea and that the threshold values ​​are specified there. This is decided as an implementing act, so to speak, jointly between the Council and the Commission, and the delegated acts remain, so to speak, with the possibility of objection by Parliament - everything that relates to the basic regulation. Thanks again to everyone involved. We have a good basis here for the common fisheries policy in the future.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Madam President, I would also like to thank the rapporteur, our colleague Marco Affronte, as well as the other shadow rapporteurs and the representatives of the institutions at the level of the trialogue. I think we have concluded a good regulation. As a shadow rapporteur by the Socialists and Democrats for this diploma, I emphasize that scientific fisheries data have been essential for knowledge-based management and decision-making. The review that we approve here opens up new possibilities for cooperation between Member States, making cooperation at regional level coherent. As I myself come from a scientific institution that deals with fishing data, I reinforce the importance of the consistency of the information collected. This new regulation also emphasizes the possibility of scientific cruises and not only the acquisition of biological data for the discharge of commercial fishing. Scientific cruises, independent of commercial fishing, are essential to complete a holistic view of resources. Another very relevant aspect is the greater transparency in access to data resulting from the programs covered by the regulation. Institutions with a valid reason will be able to request fisheries data obtained from collection systems financed at European level. This diploma will foster transparency and will certainly result in better knowledge to support better management. However, it concerns the lack of guarantees in the participation of regional authorities in the planning and collection phases. As the entities that most closely deal with the problems, in many cases, regional governments have even responsibilities in resource management and may, if that is the interpretation of the Member State, stay out of the process. I will be attentive and ensure that no one is excluded. Finally, I would also like to highlight the elegance with which the legitimacy of monitoring and implementing the program was resolved. After a lively and dense in terms of the trialogue, an effective solution was reached.The mixed approach between delegated and implementing acts legitimates the specificity of each of the European governance institutions.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: on behalf of the ECR Club. - Madam President, I thank Mr Affronte for his constructive report. Data collection and its use for the purpose of producing better data is of particular importance in the fisheries sector. If we want to ensure the right of fishermen to work and catalyze economic growth and the preservation of jobs in coastal areas, and on the other hand effectively protect marine resources, of course we must rely on relevant data. As an MP from Croatia, I am concerned that we still do not have complete data on the state of fish stocks in the Adriatic. Available data from different sources are largely mutually exclusive, so it is difficult to adopt policies that will represent a quality balance between the interests of fishermen and the protection of resources. I therefore call on the authorities at all levels to regulate this issue with as little regulation as possible, to ensure the simple collection of data that will not be a burden on fishermen and to facilitate exchanges between the competent authorities. Relevant data are key to good fisheries policies.

name: António MARINHO E PINTO
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Madam President, I would also like to start by welcoming the rapporteur and the excellent work he has done and showing solidarity with the perspective he instilled in his report, which is to emphasize the need for scientific data in order to be able to assess the impacts of fishing, not only at the level of fishing. the ability to reproduce stocks, on a quantitative level, but also and above all in terms of the environmental sustainability of this economic activity, which is so necessary for economic development and so necessary for the support of millions of families worldwide. I would like to say that sustainability must include the environmental issue. There is no sustainability if we do not protect the environment and if we are not all involved in this project and in this work to protect the environmental quality of the oceans. Only then will fisheries be sustainable, only then will fisheries be able to fulfill their economic objective. But, on the other hand, I also want to emphasize that a balance must be created between the interests of professional fishing and the interests of tourism associated with recreational fishing in certain regions. There are situations in which recreational fishermen have privileges over professional fishermen - and this is not permissible. Finally, Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the policy of collecting and consolidating data to manage fisheries policy well is only possible if there is an investment, an increase in investment in scientific research. More funds are needed for scientific research in the oceans, to enable the collection of reliable data, which can fulfill its information mission.

name: João FERREIRA
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, only a management of fisheries resources, anchored in solid scientific knowledge, will allow a rational and sustainable exploitation of these resources. The need to collect, manage and use fisheries data in sufficient quantity and quality is indisputable, as unquestionable is also the need to make these data comparable and integrable at national, regional and international levels. There is a dimension of resource management that is obviously beyond national borders, which requires genuine cooperation and committed concertation at the international level. What is questionable, however, is that these needs are better met within the framework of the centralizing vision that continues to prevail in the European Union's common fisheries policy. A vision that has a concrete expression in the institutional framework foreseen in the Lisbon Treaty, which confers exclusive competences to the European Union in this area, which has always been our disagreement. Time has shown the pernicious nature of this vision. In addition, the same European Union, which mistakenly has exclusive competence in defining the policy, throws a substantial part of the financing costs of that policy up to the States, not fully assuming, as it should, the responsibilities at the level of the financing, for example, data acquisition and management. Do we want more and better data? Yes. We want greater possibilities for scrutiny and greater transparency about their use, but we do not guarantee a vision of resource management that seems to us essentially wrong.

name: Linnéa ENGSTRÖM
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I want to start by thanking the rapporteur, my colleague Marco Affronte. I, of course, welcome the report, the negotiating agreement and the work conducted by the team. The new rules on data collection are intended to align this framework with the requirements of the reformed common fisheries policy. One of the things of particular importance to the Greens is sustainable fishing, to keep stocks above levels that can reduce maximum sustainable yield (MSY).  This is respecting the objectives of the CFP, as provided in Article 2(2) [of Regulation (EU) No 1380/2013]. Reliable stock assessment, including FMSY, is essential to establish fisheries conservation measures, and to ensure that fishing is environmentally sustainable and economically profitable.  We need reliable, comprehensive and long-term data for the purpose of decisions on fisheries management and for the protection of ecosystems, including vulnerable species and habitats. In that respect, we stress the importance of the new framework for data collection, the obligation of the Member States on collection, storage, protection and provision of data, and cooperation within, and between, the Member States. Yesterday we discussed the increasingly vulnerable situation in the Arctic. This is a real example of where we need more science and more data to better understand the unique ecosystems that are now revealed – they have never been touched by mankind, and are being revealed now that the Arctic ice is melting.

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, information is power. If you run the data you control what people think. Control thinking and you control people themselves and the choices they make. The European Union has long worked on this basis. The EU knows perfectly well that by centralising the data on fish stocks throughout Europe the UK can never escape the suffocating embrace of the common fisheries policy. If Great Grimsby, Hull, Scarborough, Whitby or any other fishing port in the UK is to have a future then we need our sovereignty back. No ifs, no buts; we need to take back full control of all our waters and the means to choose what data we collect. We decide what is monitored and when, and how, and if. Without the power to measure, analyse and utilise fishing data, the UK will still be unable to formulate its own fisheries policies and will remain under the hegemony of the CFP. This report is the Trojan horse, the cuckoo in the nest, the fifth column, the hidden enemy within. Sign up to this under the so-called Great Repeal Bill – which is no such thing – and the UK has lost half the battle to reclaim our own fisheries and waters before the negotiation has even begun. If that sounds theoretical, then just ask the artisanal, shore-based fishermen in my constituency who face losing their livelihoods following the recent sea bass ban. That ban originates in EU data and data control. Sovereignty shared is sovereignty lost.

name: Diane JAMES
text: – Madam President, it is universally acknowledged that the European Union’s common fisheries policy has created enormous environmental and economic damage: discards, overfishing, plummeting fish stocks and thousands of jobs lost. We actually already have that information, and that has led to a damaging impact on communities and cultures.  This report – and,  I emphasise, an uncosted proposal – outlines a big data response. What is actually required is a complete overhaul and revision of the existing European Union fisheries policies before this is even started. At the last plenary session here in Strasbourg, the EU cloud was approved. I spoke at that meeting and I highlighted that nearly EUR 5 billion was still identified as the shortfall for the funding. Here we have a big data project linked to the EU cloud, we have not even identified the monies to fund the EU cloud, and yet we are seemingly going to approve a big data project. It really is back to front policy.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, with high-quality data, reliable data, scientists can give accurate advice, operators can better manage their business, and we politicians can make informed decisions and produce fair laws. Everybody wins. The agreement reached by the co-legislators provides for an improved and simplified framework to collect comprehensive and reliable information and to make it available to all those involved at regional and European level. The new rules are intended to ensure that all relevant data is collected on a cost-benefit basis and without duplication of effort. It includes new types of data collection necessary for the CFP, such as ecosystem data or aquaculture data, and promotes regional and, in turn, customized solutions through the establishment of regional coordination groups. For the reform of the CFP we need data, more than ever, to measure the progressive achievement of the maximum sustainable yield, as well as the effects of the landing obligation. Therefore, this agreement is welcome. Of course, we need to see how it will work in its application, because we are concerned about what regional coordination will look like in practice, as the Regulation does not include a precise description of the role of the regional coordination groups, nor is there a very clear Regulation. It is also unclear who the end users will be, as it was decided not to include any definition in this regard. And this is a sensitive issue, as data confidentiality is vital for operators. Even in the last regional coordination meetings, the need to limit this term itself in some way has become evident, since not doing so will imply a lack of rationalization of the available resources and, possibly, not meeting the objectives that we seek in this Regulation. In any case, welcome; many congratulations to the rapporteur Affronte, my colleague Kuhn and all the shadow speakers for great work.(He agreed to answer a question asked under the "blue card" procedure (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: David COBURN
text: blue-card question. – Just a small question: do you not think that this is a French and Spanish plot to keep control of British fishing waters after Brexit?

name: Gabriel MATO
text: "blue card" response.- Obviously you know the answer.You know much more about conspiracy than we do.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: - Madam president. Good answer, Mr. Mato, to certain opinions that do not deserve other things. I want to highlight first of all the good work done by the rapporteur Affronte, by Ricardo Serrão and by all the other shadow speakers, because I think that an interesting text has been achieved for something that, in our first appreciation, is very technical. It is something technical, yes, but fundamental to make determinations. In the European Union, in fisheries, data are being collected from the 2000 framework. There was a reform in 2008 and now the Community fisheries policy requires adaptation, especially to articulate in this collection all the supporting scientific advice, which is a substantial element to achieve a great objective of the CFP, the maximum sustainable yield. Therefore, we need adequate data collection, good management of this data and its use to achieve those great objectives of the CFP that without this would not be possible - to achieve the objectives of maximum sustainable yield - or, for example, also all the collection of data that the disposal plans will give us, which will provide very interesting new data. I end by saying: in the Mediterranean there is a great deficit of data that will help us make future decisions.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, a good rule of thumb is when it combines protection and development.To create these conditions, there is a great need to collect data, to know.We, as politicians, as representatives, cannot act if we do not know, because if a rule acted only on protection or only on development it would create a total dystonia with respect to the will of politics.That is why I think that this regulation is so important - and I also thank my colleague Affronte and all those who have worked on it, Mr Kuhn - because we can see the common fisheries policy (CFP) as a great policy at our disposal.We cannot ignore economic development in Europe, especially in the coastal areas, where it is possible to reconcile more economic developments in protection and an ability not to compromise the harmony of such an important economy as that of fishing.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: - Madam President, we agree that it is very important to have the right and quality scientific data for good fisheries management, but we believe that the new framework should never interfere with the normal development of artisanal and coastal fishing activities and should not be more burdensomein economic and administrative terms for the fleets.We ask that the collection and management of data take into account the specificities of the fleet and that socio-economic and environmental data become a fundamental part of the information collected.As for socio-economic data, we also ask that the role and situation of women in fisheries - seafarers, fishermen, shellfish gatherers and other women who work in this field be highlighted.In addition, the thresholds below which it will not be necessary to collect certain data or carry out on-board campaigns should also be defined taking into account the type of fleet and its impacts on resources.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: – Madam President, the EU framework for the collection and management of fisheries data has been in place since the year 2000. Under this framework, the Member States collect, manage and make available a wide range of biological, environmental, technical and social economic data on fishing, aquaculture and processing sectors needed for scientific advice. The agreement we are discussing today includes an improved framework for gathering extensive and reliable information, and making it available at regional and European level. The improvement in data collection will enable the maximum sustainable yield to be evaluated more reliably and ensure long-term sustainability, as laid down in the basic regulation. The regulation will also update and simplify the current rules on data collection to take into account the new CFP reform, achieving maximum sustainable yield and lending obligation. The new rules will ensure that all the relevant data is collected following a cost-benefit approach and without duplication of effort, thus reducing the administrative burden. I am, therefore, in favour of this report.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this dossier deals with a deeply felt problem, especially in the Mediterranean, a sea rich in resources but characterized by a strong lack of data that would allow us to really know the state of health of our stocks. The reform of the data collection framework is therefore crucial to achieving the objectives of the CFP and requires the effort of Member States to collect the data necessary to assess the state of exploited marine biological resources, the level of fisheries and the impact of these last on biological resources and also on marine ecosystems. The collection, management and use of data must meet criteria of precision, reliability and timeliness. At the same time it is necessary to avoid that the same data is collected several times for different purposes, because this would involve an unnecessary waste of resources. In this regard, I welcome the proposal to organize a European scientific data network to use the information collected according to the assessment that is to be carried out and so that it can also be exchanged with third countries. The issue is very complex and at the same time closely connected to the need to manage fishing activities, taking into account their impact on ecosystems and that is why it should be managed according to the principle of regionalization. Furthermore, we still have much to discover about the sea and its resources, scientific knowledge is essential for efficient and far-sighted management but it is not enough, data is needed, as well as on withdrawal, also on consumption on trade and catering. There is still a lot to do on this too.

name: Czesław HOC
text: - Madam President! Harmonization of EU rules governing the collection of all data relating to the fisheries, aquaculture and processing sectors is essential for the implementation of the Common Fisheries Policy, allowing this policy to be based on the best possible scientific advice. However, I am seriously concerned and even irritated by the fact that the problem of data on industrial catch, the so-called forage in the Baltic Sea. The Baltic is a relatively shallow sea, so large industrial units are floating death factories for all the fry and fish that make up the cod food chain. They are caught for fishmeal and food. It is a rabid economy, it is a deficiency in the proper nutrition of cod, thus disrupting its natural process of reproduction and growth of this species. The Baltic Sea is slowly dying, desperately calling for help. It is high time to save cod - a fish that, according to Marek Kurlansky, changed the world and, according to the European Commission, may be forgotten.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: – Madam President, that the EU collectively, and many Member States individually, have gained immensely from Ireland’s fishing grounds since our accession in 1973 to what was then the EEC, is indisputable. It is also indisputable that when the value to the EU, with the fish taken from Ireland’s fishing grounds, is taken into account, far from being a net beneficiary of funding since joining the EU, Ireland is in fact a net contributor (pardon the pun). The question is, though: to what extent, and exactly how much, has the EU gained from Irish fishing grounds since 1973? Through a series of written questions to the Commission I have been trying to establish that figure, and have failed. Why? The reason repeatedly given is that the EU does not have the data for individual Member States and, for that reason, will not even attempt to give me an estimate. As I said, that the EU has gained from our fishing grounds is indisputable. The fact that they refuse to even give an estimate of that value from all the data they do have is not acceptable. I repeat, this is a matter of major significance for Ireland, even more so now that the EU has lost the UK. Get that data and get me that number.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: - Madam President, the collection, management and use of data is essential for the development of an efficient fishing activity and for the proper functioning of the Common Fisheries Policy.To assess the impact of fishing activity on ecosystems and fishing populations, we must have complete, reliable and harmonized data.Data collection must be adapted to new societal needs with improved transparency and efficient use of resources.Access to data should be facilitated and duplication should be avoided, promoting coordination, joining forces between States and contributing to the regionalization of fisheries management.We must also consider the gender variable throughout the data collection process, making the role of women in the fishing sector visible.This report offers progress on many of these aspects and I therefore consider it positive.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, data collection is essential for the implementation of the common fisheries policy, because it allows it to be based on objective and scientific advice. In addition to assessing the state of fish stocks, the profitability of the various segments of the sector and the impact of fisheries and aquaculture on the ecosystem, the data is needed to evaluate EU policies such as, for example, measures fisheries management and mitigation. The creation of supranational regional databases, through regional coordination groups, is important in order to have aggregated and comparable data. In the Adriatic Sea, for example, the data from Italy, Slovenia and Croatia will be evaluated overall. The data will be available to everyone - institutions, researchers, environmental associations and anyone interested in studying and evaluating them. For the first time, data from other sectors impacting the marine ecosystem, such as recreational fishing and aquaculture, will also be included in the framework for data collection and management. This is an important step forward which will contribute to favoring the sustainable development of fishing, thus limiting the impact on the marine ecosystem.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Madam President, the use of data in the fisheries sector is essential for the evaluation of Union policies, as it helps to manage fisheries and to take remedial financial measures for fisheries and aquaculture-dependent areas. At a time when the primary sector in the European Union is being tested, the Union must take steps to restructure and strengthen it. In particular, coastal and island areas face significant problems due to the economic downturn, resulting in population decline and population flight. In countries such as Greece, which is plagued by austerity and memoranda, fishermen are experiencing the effects of the agricultural memorandum, seeing their incomes fall dramatically. The European Union must help boost employment in these areas and increase funding for the fishing fleet. In particular, it must take steps to support Greek fishermen.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: - Madam President, I have cooperated with institutes operating in the Adriatic Sea, especially with those in Rovinj, but also in Trieste, Split, Ancona and I must emphasize that I am fully aware of how important it is to collect scientific data regardless of what these institutes sometimes have.somewhat conflicting data and conflicting estimates.Scientific cooperation on sensitive seas such as small closed seas, and the Adriatic Sea is such a small, closed sea, within a larger sea, the Mediterranean Sea, which is also unfortunately not sufficiently explored and we do not have enough data as far as the whole Mediterranean.I welcome this proposal and welcome the results we expect.I suggest that data on the impact of fishing and fishing on tourism be collected in order to see what traditional fishing means and to see how the health of marine organisms is.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, I would like to say thank you to the Parliament for prioritising the work on the Recast Regulation on Data Collection and, in particular, thank you to the rapporteur and his team for their work. I will make sure I give a full account of this discussion to Commissioner Vella.  We provided for transitional arrangements so that immediately after adoption and publication of the recast there is no legal vacuum. The current Multiannual Programme for Data Collection will remain applicable until replaced by a new one. There have been a couple of comments about data storage. I would just record that basic storage of data will remain at Member State level and Member States will remain responsible for ensuring that good quality data is available for end-users. The current multiannual programme was adopted last summer and it was already updated with many of the new requirements. So, there is no need to replace it urgently. The Member States’ work plans for data collection were approved last summer. Member States will already have started collecting data accordingly. When important modifications are needed, Member States will need to resubmit the work plans for approval in the normal way. Meanwhile, Member States have already started to transition from regional coordination meetings to regional coordination groups, ensuring more continuity and better involving the relevant end-users in data collection.  In summary, by the end of 2017 we expect the new legal framework for data collection to be operational for collecting all data needed for what I take to be our shared objective, the effective implementation and monitoring of the CFP. Thank you.

name: Marco AFFRONTE
text: speaker. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, just a couple of points. I would say that, apart from a few voices out of the chorus, there is great agreement on this report, not only on the importance of scientific data - it has been repeated so many times - but also - and I thank those who have expressed themselves in this sense - in the consensus on the work we have done and what we have managed to achieve. I also thank the Commission because it clarified a point that I would have clarified and that is the fact that the data are not centralized but remain at the level of the Member States, even if I am of the opinion that the interventions we have heard, especially from the extreme right, were those of those who have not actually read the document but of those who have only made his "classic" intervention. Having said that, I would like to take this opportunity to thank those who worked with me on this dossier: there was a great deal of agreement from the shadow rapporteurs of all the political groups. We have worked very well, we have tried to do things effectively but also quickly, because we know that the Member States need to be able to start with the collection as quickly as possible. We ran aground, without expecting it, for a few months with the Council for the discussion of the attribution of powers between delegated acts and acts of execution and, in the end, as someone said, we came out of it in a very effective and elegant way. It is clear that, in order to have good fishing policies and reach the goal of sustainable fishing, both from an environmental and socio-economic point of view, we cannot ignore a deep knowledge of the fish resources we are going to exploit and the consequences of our decisions. and actions on the marine environment, resources and economic sectors. To do this we need data and the entry into force of this regulation is essential to move in this direction.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place at the end of the debates.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The next item is the debate on five motions for resolutions on the case of Pastor Evan Mawarire with Zimbabwe1 (2017/2608 (RSP))._______ 1 See Minutes.

name: Geoffrey VAN ORDEN
text: author. – Madam President, Zimbabwe should be one of the most prosperous countries on the African continent. Instead, a third of its population is near starvation, relying on international food aid and brutally oppressed by a corrupt, kleptocratic regime. There is mass unemployment and hyperinflation. In fact, the country is bankrupt and its people in despair, and yet the grand architect of this misery, Robert Mugabe, continues in power.  I have been in this Parliament for 18 years and, throughout this time, have campaigned for effective action against Mugabe and for freedom for the Zimbabwean people. They desperately need our help. Today we are focusing on the plight of the latest victims in a long line of brave people who have dared to speak out against the Mugabe tyranny. We still do not know the fate of Itai Dzamara and we deplore the treatment of Pastor Evan Mawarire. The international community, including the EU, has been divided and ineffective in its measures against the Mugabe clique, but particular blame must go to those African governments that have not only turned a blind eye to Mugabe’s atrocious regime, but have lauded Mugabe himself. Shame on all that have allowed this appalling situation to drag on for so long.

name: Soraya POST
text: Author.- Madam President!Dear colleagues!As a human rights activist, the liberation struggle in southern Africa has been a guiding light.Robert Mugabe, however, went from freedom hero to tyrant, but the opposition lives in Zimbabwe.Pastor Evan Mawarire was threatened with death by the torpedoes of the dictatorship and fled to the United States.However, he had the courage to retreat to challenge this tyrant.Mawarire was arrested as soon as he landed in Harare.Mugabe's power base is also being challenged from within.Veterans of the liberation struggle, the president's old ally, boycotted Mugabe's speech this summer in protest of the dictatorship, and Evan Mawarire is now a free man.Now the regime's bloody henchmen must be brought to justice, and the indictment against Mawarire must be dropped.Friends, let us show today that Zimbabwe's democratic forces also have our support in the EU.We continue to believe in change.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: author. - Madam president. We condemn the violence and repression of peaceful demonstrations, any type of intimidation, harassment, arbitrary arrests and violence against human rights activists, the opposition, NGOs and journalists that are taking place in Zimbabwe today. We believe that every country should respect and implement international human rights conventions, including the 1998 United Nations Declaration on Human Rights Defenders. However, we reject any external operations and destabilization strategies, as well as interference in the internal affairs of Zimbabwe for mere geostrategic purposes. Let's be realistic. Problems are suffered by people. Poverty, unemployment and chronic malnutrition are the main problems facing the country, and we believe that these problems can only be solved through the implementation of an ambitious public policy plan in the areas of employment, education, health and health. agriculture, together with solidarity and international cooperation. In addition, Zimbabwe is one of the most indebted countries in the world and exemplifies, once again, that we need to address debt from a human rights-based approach and its long-term sustainability, as well as fair standards that redefine debt mechanisms. loan. Without all this, we will continue to be incoherent, using these urgent Resolutions as a carrot and stick based on economic interests and neglecting the problems of the people.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: – Madam President, I would prefer not to have to come in here and do this, but we are at the end of our tether at this stage. Potentially, up to 60 MEPs and MEPs’ assistants are not receiving their email, and their diaries are not working. We have attempted to resolve this through ITEC. ITEC does not know its elbow from its posterior, unfortunately. The administration has not contacted MEPs to tell them about the problem, and, wait for it – I hope you are looking for a bit of a laugh here – I had been told that I would be informed by email when my emails are back. Now when my emails are back, I will know because they will be back. I will not need an email to tell me. It is a complete and utter mess. We do not know when speaking time is happening, we do not know when our appointments are happening, and this is happening to up to 50, 60 people in here. Yet every time we go down to ITEC, it is as if Pol Pot has taken over: it is year zero, and they know nothing about it. It is unacceptable. You have heard the phrase about being able to ‘run a piss-up in a brewery’? Well, you have failed. Can you sort it out? Can Mr Tajani sort it out? The 125 000 people who voted for me would like to know that I will know when my appointments are and when I have to turn up to work. It is fairly basic. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Representative, I understand your remarks from the first three sentences.

name: Geoffrey VAN ORDEN
text: – Madam President, may I just say what a pity it is that this very serious debate about a tragic matter and a country in Africa which has been ruined by the despoliation of this dictator Mugabe is interrupted by what can only be seen as relative trivia, and I would call for no more interruptions of that nature. (Applause)

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: There are no more opportunities to comment, we will not divert the discussion from the topic.I understand, I also see the representative's application, I understand your request, I will forward it, we will look into it and we will signal back.It’s practically not an email that you don’t know what’s going on, but they will contact you in person and investigate the matter.I will forward your request to the Bureau.We return to the list.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: author. – Madam President, one has to have a very strong stomach to interrupt a debate on the tragic situation in Zimbabwe with an administrative IT issue.  This is, and is not, a motion about the case of Pastor Evan Mawarire. Why is it about him? Because it is a tragic case. Why is it not just about him? Because this is yet another case out of hundreds of thousands in a country which should be flourishing, but which is sinking and sinking. We will surely have more debates about more motions for resolutions on Zimbabwe, on concrete cases, but what we really need is a serious debate. We need to implement the policy tools that we have at our disposal, limited as they are, vis—à—vis Zimbabwe and other African countries. Otherwise, we will have an inflation in the number of resolutions with no change. What we really need is a change for the better and an improvement. This is something that the EU has to do. If it is not capable of doing it, that it is a very negative sign.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: author. - Madam President! I will only focus on the facts. President Mugabe's government has repeatedly violated the rule of law, civil liberties are being restricted, and corruption has effectively inhibited the country's development. As freedom of expression, freedom of association and assembly are enshrined in the Zimbabwean constitution, reports of governmental actions against Pastor Mawarire and other human rights defenders, including Itai Dzamara, who went missing under mysterious circumstances, are very disturbing. Numerous public protests calling for improvement in the economic situation and respect for human rights were brutally suppressed by the government, and despite his release, the pastor was presented with politically motivated charges. Respect for human rights is an essential element of ACP-European Union cooperation under the Cotonou Agreement, to which Zimbabwe is a signatory. Therefore, the country's authorities must stop repressing human rights defenders and opposition representatives. This is very important, especially in the context of next year's presidential elections.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: for the PPE Group.- Madam President, I want to join in and support this resolution, I join the work of my colleagues in proposing this resolution, which criticizes the current state of Zimbabwe.The whole debate today was sparked by the situation of the specific human rights defender, Pastor Mawarire.But it is right that the debate is not only about this person being unduly politically prosecuted, but also about the overall human rights situation in Zimbabwe.The situation and the state of human rights, freedom of expression, freedom of assembly and other constitutional rights, which are constantly being suppressed in Zimbabwe, must be clearly described in plenary here and condemned in the country.It must be made clear that if Zimbabwe wants money from the EU, then it needs to respect human rights in order to respect the fundamental principles of democracy.It is also necessary to check where the money from the EU flows and whether it is not stolen by the local public authorities.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Madam President! Zimbabwe is a great country with unimaginable potential. For many years, however, it has been held hostage by a corrupt and authoritarian regime and robbed of its future prospects. All those who raise this issue and who urge the observance of human rights are made enemies of the state, like Pastor Evan Mawarire and many others. They are silenced with flimsy arguments. But there will soon be elections again that offer a chance for a new beginning. Everything must be done to ensure that they are fair. The European Union must position itself clearly with election observers. Above all, free access to information is needed in the run-up to the elections. Social media restrictions must be lifted. Radio licenses for private and community and non-profit organizations must be enabled. Above all, however, the politicization of food aid by the government must be stopped.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, unfortunately, this is not the first resolution we have made on Zimbabwe: the case of Pastor Mawarire is unfortunately not an isolated case. The EU restrictive measures against the Zimbabwe regime were renewed in February 2017 for a period of one year, as well as the arms embargo maintained, while the asset freeze and travel ban will continue to be applied to President Mugabe. At the same time, the European Union, through the National Indicative Program for Zimbabwe, has allocated EUR 234 million for the period 2014-2020. I believe that we must act, leveraging these tools at our exposure if we want to see any improvement or any significant progress in the area of ​​human rights, because unfortunately we have not seen any from the resolutions we approved previously. Evan Mawarire must be able to enjoy fundamental and inalienable rights and freedoms just like any other citizen of Zimbabwe and the same must be true for all political prisoners arrested only for expressing dissent against a government, against which one cannot other than to disagree.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: on behalf of the ENF Group.- Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we too support this resolution, as an act of support for the struggle for freedom and democracy of these African leaders subjected to corrupt and bloodthirsty regimes.However, there are some doubts: the European Union is committed to monitoring that aid for the national indicative program reaches the sectors intended.This does not happen regularly, neither in Zimbabwe nor in other countries.The European Union must make a serious and concrete commitment to make sure that this EUR 234 million of aid goes not to the corrupt but to the populations.And then, can you tell us something about the compensation due to farmers who were violently expropriated, with terrible acts, by the military forces that came from the war of independence?And then Mugabe's blatantly racist statements against whites: why doesn't he condemn black and white?

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Madam President, from economic powerhouse to financial ruin, from the breadbasket of Africa to starvation, the Mugabe regime continues to do what it has sadly always done: run Zimbabwe into the ground. As far back as I can remember, Mugabe has acted in this way, retaining a veneer of democracy whilst acting in a despotic and undemocratic way. This persecution of political opponents is nothing new. The same was done to Morgan Tsvangirai over a number of years from 2000 to 2008, with persecution and violence against those Mugabe did not agree with. The rights of Pastor Evan Mawarire, who so far as I can see has done nothing wrong, are being trampled upon. We do not even know what is happening to Mr Itai Dzamara. We have seen assets of Mugabe frozen, yet at the same time a large amount of money is being sent to Zimbabwe in aid and we need to make absolutely sure that we know what we are doing, that we know why it is being done, and that we ensure that money is not going to the wrong places. I have grave concerns that may well be happening.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: - Madam President, Robert Mugabe has presided over the Republic of Zimbabwe for almost 30 years. A true autocrat, he exhibits the characteristics of the rogue politicians who dominate Africa. A claimed anti-white racist, Mr. Mugabe has turned his country into hell on earth. While the population enjoys few individual rights, this is not the worst of the evils that afflicts them. Starvation, inflation and police repression follow one another at regular intervals. In this terrible context, the censorship of opponents is intolerable. Arrested as soon as he got off the plane last February, Pastor Evan Mawarire was finally released on bail. He plans to run in the next election. Robert Mugabe must drop charges of attempted government sabotage and incitement to violence against Mr. Mawarire. More generally, Africa will not be able to develop if the institutions of the states that compose it do not evolve.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: - Madam President, our group, the EPP Group, took the initiative to discuss Zimbabwe six months after the last debate on this country.Unfortunately, what I was saying then only confirms the case of Pastor Mawarire.Instead of addressing citizens' concerns through political and economic reforms, the Mugabe regime continues to limit the right to free speech and persecute human rights defenders.Pastor Mawarire only called on the government to reform and respect human rights.Because of this, he is being prosecuted and is liable to imprisonment for up to twenty years.These accusations are obviously politically motivated and I think we should all stand up for Pastor Mawarire.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Zimbabwe is experiencing a profound economic crisis, with a very high rate of unemployment and widespread corruption at all political and administrative levels. Some citizens, since last summer, have begun to respond with numerous anti-government demonstrations. In this climate the activist for the rights of the most dispossessed, the Baptist pastor Evan Mawarire, considered the Martin Luther King of Zimbabwe, has become the symbol of the protest, which calls for transparency in government action and dignity for every citizen of Zimbabwe. For his political activity Mawarire was arrested on charges of conspiracy against the state. The pastor is now on probation but faces a sentence of up to 20 years. The charge of subversion was called completely fabricated by his lawyers. It is clear that the trial of the opposition leader in Zimbabwe responds only to the political needs of the current government. The European Union and the international community must take an active part to allow the immediate release of Evan Mawarire and to restore democratic viability in the country.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Madam President, I support the resolution, which I have co-signed. Pastor Evan Mawarire was arrested by Zimbabwean police while on trial for allegedly hoisting the Zimbabwean flag without permission. This act is considered a criminal offense because this symbol was used by anti-government protesters in their mobilizations against the President of Zimbabwe. We therefore condemn the arrest of Mawarire, as well as the journalists and activists who have also been arrested. Zimbabwe must embark on deep democratic reforms, guarantee freedom of thought, expression, media freedom, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, and, of course, stop human rights abuses. and take action to address malnutrition affecting the country.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, honourable Members, thank you for this resolution. The recent arrest of Pastor Mawarire is, unfortunately, another case that raises important concerns about what is going on in Zimbabwe. The EU, through its delegation in Zimbabwe, has been following the case closely. Together with representatives from the Member States, we attended Pastor Mawarire’s High Court bail application hearing on 8 February. We welcome the positive ruling at the High Court to grant bail, and we take careful note of the judge’s remarks about the weakness of the State’s case. The case has been raised with the government at senior level, and we will continue to follow developments closely.  The right of Pastor Mawarire to express his views and opinions in a peaceful manner is a fundamental freedom enshrined in Zimbabwe’s own Constitution. Human rights defenders, organisations and activists are playing a critical role in the promotion of human rights in Zimbabwe. It is essential that they are free to operate in an environment that protects fundamental human rights and freedoms, as set out in Zimbabwe’s Constitution. They deserve recognition and credit for their significant and persistent contribution. The EU is committed to fighting discrimination, to preserving the rights of individuals to enjoy the full range of human rights in Zimbabwe, and we are determined to continue supporting the work of civil society organisations and protecting human rights activists.  Zimbabwe is at a critical juncture, as a number of you have said. Continued political and economic reforms are essential to restore growth and achieve inclusive and sustainable development. Respect for the rule of law, human rights and the consolidation of democracy are also essential. The electoral commission should engage with all parties to agree on an electoral framework for the 2018 elections. Our overall objective remains to re-engage fully with a stable and democratic Zimbabwe. I would like to recall the EU’s continuing commitment to the people of Zimbabwe and emphasise that the EU remains amongst the most important donors to that country.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: I have received five motions for resolutions.I close the debate.The vote will take place at the end of the debates.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing.- The arrest of Pastor Evan Mawarire, given the evident politicization of the accusations against him, appears as a use, by the Zimbabwean authorities, of the criminal justice system to target human rights defenders.In Zimbabwe, expressing an opinion in a non-violent way is a constitutional right for all citizens and it is an obligation of the authorities to protect it, however, for many years the people of Zimbabwe have been oppressed by an authoritarian regime led by President Mugabe, who remains in powerthrough corruption and violence.It is important for the EU to enter into political dialogue with the Zimbabwean authorities, under the Cotonou Agreement, to support the local population.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: in writing.- Zimbabwe, one of the poorest countries in the world, is in a very precarious situation.There are constant human rights violations and attacks on the opposition in the country.It should be noted that freedom of assembly, association and expression are key components of democracy.All states must respect and uphold human rights.The Zimbabwean authorities need to step up their efforts to prevent violent repression, political violence and restrictions and intimidation of human rights defenders.The criminal justice system must not be abused.Human rights defenders must be facilitated in their activities.Given the current situation and support for the local population, the EU should enter into a political dialogue with the Zimbabwean authorities in accordance with the Cotonou Agreement.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The next item is the debate on five motions for resolutions on Ukrainian political prisoners in Russia and the situation in Crimea1 (2017/2596 (RSP))._______ 1 See Minutes.

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: Author. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen from the Verkhovna Rada! Anyone who has visited the Crimean Tatars at home on the peninsula in recent years knows what the renewed loss of their homeland and the loss of all their rights means for this group of Ukrainian citizens, who knows what it means a few decades after their rehabilitation Against the persecution under Stalin to be at the center of systematic criminalization and persecution. I think it is good that colleagues from all the other groups have come to an understanding with all of us to adopt this resolution today with a very broad consensus against the annexation of Crimea, against the ongoing occupation of Crimea. It is for the Ukrainians in Crimea and it is extremely important for the Ukrainians in their country that we show solidarity against the injustice, against the violation of international law by Russia. When we worked out this resolution, which of course relates very strongly and with good reason to the Crimea, new facts were created in the areas of Luhansk and Donetsk which were occupied with Russian aid. Not only is the ruble a means of payment in the Luhansk area, but Russian passports are recognized and Ukrainian companies are nationalized. Dear colleagues from the Rada! I would like to use this debate as an opportunity to say again that the sanctions that the European Union has adopted against breaches of international law must not be called into question. With these sanctions we defend security and order on this continent. Those who repeatedly question the sanctions are not only endangering the people who get caught up in the injustice mills of Russian persecution in Crimea or in eastern Ukraine, they are also endangering the future of security and stability on the entire continent.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: author. – Madam President, we commemorate the sad anniversary of the illegal annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation. We have to remember that the Crimean Tatars are the indigenous people who have been living there for centuries, intimidated by the imperial will of earlier Russian Tsars, then by Stalin, and now by Putin’s regime. They were offered open annexation and a political deal, a puppet autonomy under Russian rule, for acceptance of the annexation. They are people of honour and therefore refused this deal. Then intimidation and mass violation of their human rights started, including the delegalisation of their political representation, the Mejlis, and the pronouncement that this respectable body had terrorist links. We have had the opportunity to listen to the families of people who perished under Russian rule. Mustafa Dehermendzhy was arrested for actions taken before the annexation. The same happened to other people.

name: Soraya POST
text: Author.- Madam President!War and dictatorship are the worst enemies of human rights.Both have made horrific comebacks in Europe.Perhaps the biggest threat today is Vladimir Putin.For the first time since World War II, he has refurnished European borders by force.Behind these new frontiers, he has put human rights on the grill.62 Ukrainian citizens have been illegally prosecuted in Russia for political reasons.17 are illegally detained in the Russian Federation and 15 in Crimea.Hundreds are being held hostage in occupied eastern Ukraine.When an independent country in Europe is attacked by force, it is an attack on all of us.When human rights are trampled on, all Democrats must stand up.Today, let us raise our voices, ladies and gentlemen, so that we can be heard all the way to the Kremlin.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: author. – Madam President, Commissioner, Ukrainian friends and colleagues, the Russian Federation is 26 times bigger by territory than our host country, France. That looks like more than enough living space, does it not? No, it does not, and Putin decides to occupy Crimea. No wonder. For Russian tsars and Bolsheviks, for Stalin, and now Putin, politics has always been about expansion and domination. To destroy the Europeanisation of neighbouring nations, to deport and suppress those who protest – this is the line of the Kremlin. Next to the Kurils and Sakhalin in the East, the Kola Peninsula in the North, Kaliningrad in the West, Crimea – once an attractive summer resort – is being rapidly built as a military stronghold in the South. From 12 000 military personnel before occupation up to a figure of double that today, and 43 000 in the near future, this is the ‘Russian world’ in Crimea. A so-called ‘new world’ in Crimea is being built at the expense of the oppression of Crimean Tatars and Ukrainian citizens.  Colleagues, Russia is surely back to its imperial military posture and we must take it absolutely seriously. Abkhazia and Ossetia, Transnistria and Crimea are not coincidences; these are all parts of the Kremlin’s plan, just as Syria is today, and as Libya might be tomorrow.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: I would like to inform all those who are in the gallery, by the way, so that they refrain from expressing any kind of opinion, because according to our procedure, this is not possible.And MPs have complained about that - rightly so.So they can neither express themselves nor comment on what is happening here in the Chamber.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: author. – Madam President, we are here today to express the voice of all 28 nations in Europe in support of Ukrainian political prisoners, and to demonstrate our solidarity with the Crimean Tatars. Let me recognise, in this connection, the NGO Open Dialog, whose project ‘LetMyPeopleGo’ is doing the most valuable work in providing information about political prisoners and defending them. Our resolution, which is to be adopted soon, is strong and clear, and voices an unprecedented unity amongst practically all political groups. However, it all comes down to concrete actions by the EU governments.  I think it is high time to give up on false illusions that one could have a deal with aggressors. We need not to just tiptoe on sanctions, but strike with all force on the secret bank accounts of those responsible, and deny them entry into the EU. Ukrainian friends, you should know that the representatives of the 28 European nations will never be silent – and we will never abandon you – until all prisoners are free and the occupation of your country is ended. (Applause)

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, March 2017 marks the third sad anniversary of the illegal annexation of the Crimean peninsula by the Russian Federation. While time has passed, the illegal occupation of Ukraine’s territory continues and the human rights situation in Crimea has significantly deteriorated. At least 39 people are being held in detention in Crimea on trumped—up charges, while the practice of the transfer of detainees to distant regions of Russia still continues. Moreover, systematic violations of human rights, the use of torture and degrading treatment of political prisoners have been recorded by various organisations such as the UN Human Rights Monitoring Mission and Amnesty International.  Too much time has passed to continue as if nothing had happened. I urge the Commission to immediately address Russia with a demand that the political oppression on the Crimean peninsula be stopped. I call on the Council to consider further restrictive measures to be imposed on individuals responsible for gross human rights violations, including the freezing of assets in EU banks. We need to continue to show our solidarity with our Ukrainian friends in these difficult times.

name: Marju LAURISTIN
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, dear colleagues and Ukrainian friends, today we are gathering here at the time when the sad anniversary of the third year of occupation of Crimea falls. At the same time, Russian officials and Russian media are cynically celebrating the occupation of Crimea as a national victory. They even plan to shift the elections in Russia to celebrate the occupation of Crimea.  It is very important we show that all Europeans recognise that this is annexation, that it is illegal and that, on 16 December last year, the United Nations General Assembly officially condemned the occupation and called for it not to be recognised. For those who are not firm in support of this, we have to remind them that it is not the first time in history. From the history of the Baltic countries we know how important this politics of non-recognition is, and how important international support is for occupied countries. I call on us to be firm to support the organisations who are fighting for human rights ...  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, three years since Russia’s annexation of Crimea, it is important that we continue to demonstrate our resolve in stating that Crimea is, and remains, an integral part of Ukraine, and to stand in solidarity with those that are suffering under the military occupation. Maintaining this resolve, in which the rule of law and peaceful relations triumph against the ‘might is right’ dogma and spheres of influence espoused by Putin, is essential for the European Union.  Many will remember the visit of Mr Dzhemiliev, leader of the Crimean Tatars, to this House last year and the moving accounts he gave. The personal events of his life have been mirrored in the turbulent history of Crimea, and it is a tragedy that in 2017 we are seeing further destabilisation. For the second time in his life Dzhemiliev has been banned from entering his homeland, whilst for those able to remain from his community, economic conditions and the human rights situation have declined. Cases of disappearances and allegations of arbitrary arrest and torture are very concerning. As we saw in the case of South Ossetia, annexation is assumed by the Kremlin to result in only a temporary cooling of relations with the West, only later to be forgotten. We cannot allow this to happen again with Crimea. To do so would be to embolden the plans of President Putin in his quest to reassert control in the former Soviet space by aggressive territorial expansion.

name: Urmas PAET
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, first and foremost, Russia must stop the aggression in Ukraine. It must live up to the Minsk Agreements and stop the annexation of Crimea. However, given the reality that Russia is the occupying power in Crimea, it has the responsibility to protect the people in Crimea. However, they are doing the opposite. They prosecute innocent people for political reasons, then they prosecute people protecting those innocent people, such as, for example, their lawyers. The human rights situation has deteriorated significantly, and this needs to stop.  Russia claimed that the people in Crimea wanted to be freed from Ukraine and that they wanted to join with Russia. If Russian occupation in Crimea is a blessing to the people there, then why do you need to prosecute and harass the Tatars, Ukrainians and even Russians themselves there? The harassment, prosecutions and human rights violations must stop, and all those responsible must be brought to justice.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, almost 10,000 killed, more than 22,000 wounded and a huge number of refugees, 2.3 million of them to Russia. This is the current balance of the armed conflict in Ukraine. And don't see the end yet. It is, of course, right to show interest in the individual destinies of people who have become political prisoners. I, too, fully support us from fully criticizing imprisonment for political opinions or acts that do not conflict with democratic laws. However, in the interest of the fate of individuals, we must not forget the suffering of millions. Their pain may be anonymous, it cannot be attributed to media-pleasing stories, but it is significant. Why, for example, do we not strongly demand an examination of the burning of innocents in Odessa? Such an approach seems to me to be reprehensibly dangerous and cowardly. Our task is to help find a way to end the war in Ukraine and not to pour oil on the fire by standing on only one side of suffering.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, on the third anniversary of the illegal annexation of Crimea, the Russian Federation is celebrating reunification. However, with our resolution, we must be determined to shed light on what is really happening in Crimea. It is tragic to see the lawlessness and the repression of civil, political and human rights in Crimea, including the situation of the political prisoners, some of whom have been transferred to remote regions of the Russian Federation. We also have to give our full support and sympathy to the Tatars, the original indigenous people of Crimea. We very much appreciated the visit of their speaker, Mr Dzhemiliev, who was here a few months ago. We have to condemn the prohibition and ban of the Tatar Parliament, and we have to make sure that civil, political and human rights are returned to everyone on the peninsula. However, the situation will of course not change as long as the Russian Federation stays as an occupying power. We have to recognise the full sovereignty, independence and territorial integrity of Ukraine, including Crimea, and we have to continue the policy of non-recognition.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen! It is completely undisputed that international law and human rights have been violated on all sides in this conflict. But, Ms. Harms, you contributed to this. Among other things, it was the Association Agreement that further fueled an already heated political mood. You yourself are not afraid to praise neonationalists like fighter pilot Nadia Savchenko when your fight - yes, Ms. Harms, you are not a friend of Ukraine, you fight your fight against Russia, and that is something completely different. On Monday the Russia sanctions, which are now shamefully “restrictive measures against actions that threaten the territorial integrity, sovereignty and independence of Ukraine”, were extended to September 2017. You will not create peace by doing this either, but rather you will prevent negotiations that Ukraine will have to conduct with Russia. The European Union is of no help here. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: blue-card question. – The Association Agreement between the EU and Ukraine has been decided by the sovereign Parliament of Ukraine several times and voted through by several governments of Ukraine. As with many other association agreements with our neighbours, this was not imposed by the European Union. My question is: does my colleague think it is up to Russia to decide with whom a sovereign nation like Ukraine should trade, have agreements, or have relations? Is it for Russia to decide how its neighbouring countries should conduct relations with the rest of Europe and the world?

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.Colleague!You know very well that more has happened than the Ukrainian parliament accepted.Usually you accuse us of falling back on formalism.They know very well that beforehand, NGOs and a lot of European money had been used to create a massive mood in order to achieve exactly that.And you put pressure on to force Ukraine on an anti-Russia course.And yes, in the end Parliament took part in this game, that is correct.That was - it must and can be said now - a mistake.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI). - Mr President, it is a criminal act when a country invades another country's territory with its armed forces, carries out evictions, destroys places of worship, confiscates property and violates every notion of human rights. I am referring to Turkey, which in 1974 occupied 1/3 of the territory of the Republic of Cyprus and continues to commit crimes against a Member State of the Union, without acknowledging its existence. The European Union unjustifiably considers the peaceful annexation of Crimea a case of illegal invasion and accuses, imposes sanctions and punitive policies on Russia. In Turkey, on the other hand, it gives billions, promises membership and tolerates Erdogan's dictatorial behavior. This is hypocrisy and shows that the Union does not care about its citizens and places its geopolitical geostrategic interests above human dignity and justice. Finally, I would like to point out that it is unacceptable in European Parliament reports to ask the Council to put pressure on the International Court of Justice. The separation of powers is constitutionally enshrined and any attempt to emancipate justice refers to Stalin-type democracies.

name: Sandra KALNIETE
text: – Mr President, this resolution will give a glimmer of hope to the hundreds of Ukrainian citizens who are being illegally detained and held hostage by Russia. It should remind Putin that no—one is forgotten and nothing is forgotten. Russia’s war against Ukraine is not forgotten. The illegal annexation of Crimea is not forgotten. The fate of innocent victims is not forgotten. There should be no normalisation of any relations with Russia without the release of these political prisoners. Let us make this clear to Putin and his political and business partners in Europe. It is very important that Russia should be legally defined as an occupying power under the Geneva Convention on the protection of civilians in occupied territories. I strongly believe that Russian leaders should be held accountable for gross and systematic violations of human rights in occupied territories.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - Mr President, Europe must not stand idly by to put these patriots under the influence of the aggressor, to imprison them, to torture them. But beyond that, I believe that the European Union and the High Representative in general should play a much more active, determined and visible role for the local population in restoring peace in Ukraine, reversing Putin's aggressive expansion. And we must continue these efforts in the knowledge that the aggressor cannot be curbed by indulgence.
