The illegal occupation and militarization of Crimea, and the cruel and cynical Russian behavior about the fate of the Ukrainian patriots there, also warn us that the EU can only stand up to the Putin provocations with determination and unity. And if a government of a Member State undermines this unity in its own political interests, courtes Putin and serves its purposes, it exposes Europe as a specific, direct security risk.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: - Dozens of Ukrainian citizens are today in Russian jails for crimes they never committed. They are hostages of the undeclared Russian war against Ukraine. They are arbitrarily arrested because they write articles, for example, or because they step down in a demonstration or simply because they are Crimean Tatar. They are then tortured to make a confession for things they never did. What is behind that Russian method? Well, our citizens need to know that the reason is very transparent. The Kremlin wants its citizens to believe that they are in grave danger and that strong authority must protect them. It reinforces the tune and lie of the Russian state media that Ukraine is the number 1 enemy of the state. The aggressor then suddenly becomes a victim. Crimea was illegally annexed three years ago, and despite all international condemnations, Russia continues to occupy Crimea. Our lesson must be: whoever wants to enforce respect for international law must also hold on to the sanctions against those who violate that law. Anyone who really means human rights must tighten up sanctions against those who continue to blatantly violate these rights.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Mr President, honourable Ukrainian friends, I very much welcome that the European Parliament is today strongly condemning Russia’s occupation of Crimea and its disastrous consequences for ordinary citizens, three years after the illegal annexation of the peninsula. Crimea is just a few hours away by plane and still it has become a human rights black hole. Neither the Council of Europe nor the United Nations have access to the peninsula and they cannot monitor the situation there. Discriminatory policies are imposed on Crimean Tatars, fundamental freedoms, such as freedom of speech and association, are constantly violated, and Europe is looking away. It is shameful, and it is also shameful to listen to our colleagues who support the Russian oppression. The EU must make it perfectly clear to Russia that the occupation of Crimea will never be accepted or recognised, that the respect of human rights in Crimea is not on the table for negotiation.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: - Mr President, dear colleagues, the situation is ideological and reason does not prevail. I would like to recall the historical context. In February 2014, the Western powers signed a document for a democratic transition, the events of Maidan were a real coup and there was an interruption of the rule of law. This is a legal fact. Faced with this, Russia occupied Crimea which had been given - it must be said - by a decree in 1954 by Khrushchev and there was a referendum on free self-determination. We are facing a complicated legal situation because indeed, on the one hand, we have what we signed, which did not materialize, and therefore a breach of the rule of law and another situation of breach. I just want to point out with regard to the occupation in Crimea, where there has been real self-determination, that the human rights situation is not worse today than yesterday and therefore we must keep it right. . (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: a question asked by raising a blue card.- Dear colleague, if everyone thought like you and behaved according to what you tell us here, then I, as a citizen of the Czech Republic, could never be here, because there would still be a Czechoslovak Socialist Republic and there would be a Warsaw Pact.I want to ask you: do you recognize the right of citizens to take to the streets and demonstrate for your free rights?

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: answer "blue card".- Madam, I would first like to tell you - and no one will be able to dispute it, since there are witnesses - that the various movements of opposition to the communist system met in my house, before the fall of the wall, andthat I was therefore an important actor in everything that concerns this anti-communist action.This is history, these are facts.No one can dispute it, those who were present can testify.This is the first thing I want to say.To answer you, I would also like to say that my country, France, the Senate, the National Assembly, have taken positions which are those that I am currently expressing.You must have respect for national policy.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: - Mr President, it is now outdated to cram people into cattle and deport them.Josef Stalin allowed himself these methods when he deported Chechens, Ingush, and the Crimean Tatars.Today, much more subtle methods are used in the world than the forced migration of entire nations.There is no need to move a nation, it is enough to create an atmosphere of fear in a sophisticated way and people move out on their own.This method is used against Crimean Tatars by today's Russia, which has been illegally occupying the Crimean Peninsula for the third year in a row.Kidnappings, murders, abuse of anti-terrorism laws, abuse of psychiatric hospitals, morning digging up the door of hard-working Crimean Tatar families are very effective means.It is our duty to take the side of the hard-pressed Crimean Tatar nation.Ukrainian citizens illegally detained in Russia and the Occupied Territories must be released as soon as possible and unconditionally.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: – Mr President, Crimea has now been occupied by Russia for three years. Unfortunately, many of our expectations have been confirmed. Crimea is a concern to humanitarian and human rights organisations, civil liberties and freedoms have been curtailed, repressions against ethnic Crimean Tatars and Ukrainians have been growing, forced imposition of Russian citizenship has become systematic, and the number of political prisoners is on the rise.  We need to be concerned. Crimea is Europe’s traumatic spot. We need to be concerned about the ongoing situation there, about Russia’s responsibility for abuse of human rights in Crimea and, not least, about political prisoners being placed in Russian penal colonies because of their denial of the occupation. We should make sure that Crimea will not become a black hole in Europe which will traumatise generations to come.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the authors of this resolution, who speaks in a clear voice and says in clear words what the situation is in Crimea and what our reaction is.The European Parliament supports the unity and territorial integrity of Ukraine.Within the internationally recognized borders, it condemns Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea and supports effective sanctions.We condemn the persecution and bullying of opponents and the persecution of the Crimean Tatars.We demand their release.The Crimean Tatars who are persecuted are ordinary people, artists, teachers, small traders, and many of them have been sentenced to prison and sent to prison camps.What I consider to be a very important signal is that this is a common position of five political factions across countries, across political factions with the exception of extremists.It is a clear signal to Russia and also a clear support for Ukraine.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank Open Dialogue Foundation for the work they continue to do to expose the Russian State’s systematic abuse of human rights, and also the international campaign Let My People Go, which deserves more support and recognition.  I would especially like to raise the case of Ukrainian film—maker Oleg Sentsov, who was a rising star in the international film scene before his unlawful arrest. I would also like to thank Belarus Free Theatre for their production ‘Burning Doors’, which tells his story. True and meaningful peace can only come about through intercultural dialogue and cultural diplomacy. That is why artists and creators have such an important role to play in developing better democracies. The Russian Government must immediately release Sentsov and all prisoners it holds illegally, investigate reports of torture and give reparations to victims.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - Russia has caused an unacceptable situation in the Crimea with systematic attacks on the Crimean Tatar community, serious violations of the fundamental rights of the minority community, a ban on the Majlis and the closure of Ukrainian schools. This Russian policy is all the more incomprehensible, because in Ukraine it is the violations against the Russian minority there, the disregard for the linguistic rights of the Russian-speaking minority, that have been called for. We now see that for a large country, only its own are important and the same principles that it holds others accountable for are no longer valid and binding on themselves. It is important that the European Union does not make the same mistake and consistently stands up for human rights, including the rights of minorities. We are blaming Russia and Ukraine for these violations, but we will not leave them without a word in their own Member States. Otherwise, we will easily become unreliable and therefore our criticisms will have no weight.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, dear colleagues, more than 60 Ukrainian citizens have been illegally prosecuted for political reasons. The Russian Federation, as an occupying power, has a responsibility to ensure the safety of the entire population and respect for the human, cultural and religious rights of the indigenous Tatars and all other minorities in Crimea. Moreover, Russia should immediately cease its prosecution practices and effectively investigate all cases of human rights violations, including enforced disappearances, arbitrary detentions, torture and ill-treatment of detainees. Mykola Semena, who is facing charges of separatism, is yet more proof of the ongoing repression and terrible deterioration of free expression and free media. Finally, I would like to underline that Russian courts are not competent to judge acts committed outside the internationally-recognised territory of Russia. Crimea is a region that will always be part of Ukraine.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: - Mr President, first of all, I want to greet our Ukrainian friends here. It is not the first time that, in this House, we have condemned the illegal annexation of Crimea and Sevastopol by Russia and the systematic use of persecutions, kidnappings, torture, arbitrary arrests and extrajudicial executions to reduce the peninsula to silence and submission. For political reasons, 45 Ukrainian citizens are currently being held in unworthy and inhuman conditions. It is to them, the Tatars, who have lived in Crimea for centuries and to all Ukrainians who have been fighting for the territorial integrity of their country for three years, that, once again, we need to send a clear political signal of the support that is passing, not only for condemning these systematic human rights violations, but also for the full application of the Association Agreement with the European Union and the entry into force of the immediate liberalization of visa regimes. We cannot allow these urgent steps to be held hostage to the electoral calendars of several Member States, in some of which movements and parties arise which those who courageously fight for Maidan's values ​​can teach lessons about what it means to be truly European. Mr. President, je suis ukranien, today and always.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I see that Mr Notis Marias is absent, which is a pity. (End of catch-the-eye procedure)

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, I would like to thank Honourable Members for this resolution. As has been underlined, on Saturday we will mark the third anniversary of the illegal annexation of the Crimean Peninsula by Russia. The EU is following with great concern the deterioration of the human rights situation on the peninsula. Let us be clear: arrests and arbitrary detentions, ill-treatment, abusive use of anti-extremism legislation and violations of due process represent grave human rights violations. These target especially the Crimean Tatars and people who reject the illegal annexation.  The EU calls for a thorough investigation of these cases and the bringing to justice of those responsible. Increasingly frequent attacks on the vital work conducted by human rights defenders, such as human rights lawyers Emil Kurbedinov and Nikolay Polozov, represent worrying developments. Forced psychiatric examinations of the Deputy Chairman of the Mejlis, Ilmi Umerov, Emir Hussein Kuku, Eider Saledinov and Rustam Ismailov, are clear violations of international human rights standards. The EU continues to call for full, free and unhindered access of international human rights mechanisms to the peninsula. The EU stands ready to work with the UN and other international organisations to implement Resolution 71/205 on the situation of human rights in Crimea and Sevastopol, adopted by the General Assembly last December. The EU follows the situation closely and has repeatedly urged Russia to release all illegally held Ukrainian citizens, whether held in Russia or in the illegally annexed Crimean Peninsula. Representatives from EU delegations and Member States’ embassies in Moscow have been present in court hearings and are in contact with the lawyers.  The EU also raises individual cases – such as those of Oleg Senstov, Olexander Kolchenko, Stanislav Klich and Mykola Karpyuk – in bilateral meetings with Russian representatives, as well as in public statements, including in international fora such as the Council of Europe and the OSCE. Human rights must be respected fully in the illegally annexed Crimean Peninsula. The right to legal counsel and access to consular officers needs to be fully respected. Access to healthcare needs to be ensured. In this regard we also follow with concern the case of journalist Mykola Semena. Finally, let me restate that the European Union remains committed to implement fully its policy of non-recognition of the illegal annexation of Crimea and Sevastopol. We fully support the sovereignty, the independence and the territorial integrity of Ukraine.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: in writing.- I welcome the final resolution on the protection of Ukrainian political prisoners and Crimean Tatars, which has been carried out by Russia, and against the illegal annexation of the Crimean peninsula.One of the EU's tasks is to prevent the war situation in its neighborhood from becoming a frozen conflict and to help stabilize the country as soon as possible.Ukraine has declared its European integration aspirations and must therefore not be left alone in the difficult situation it is in.It is also the EU's responsibility to ensure that Ukraine can carry out the reform process and become a democratic state governed by the rule of law, free from the influence of Russian traditions and independent of Russian influence.The protection of human rights and the protection of indigenous minorities must also be the responsibility of the EU!

name: Indrek TARAND
text: in writing. – As an MEP from Estonia, I personally know what Soviet or Russian occupation means and feels like. Believe me, it is not fun at all. After 50 years of occupation, Estonia managed to regain independence and, through hard work, fortunately managed to join the European Union and NATO in 2004. Unfortunately, Ukraine did not share the same fate. Ukraine was duped, with the Budapest Memorandum in 1994, by a promise that if it got rid of its nuclear arsenal, the Russian Federation would honour its sovereignty. The UK and the USA promised to safeguard this pact. In 2017, Ukraine is in a state of war with Russia, the UK and the USA did not safeguard the pact, the Crimean peninsula is occupied, Russia has arrested a vast number of Ukrainian political prisoners, Russia is restricting access to Crimea for the OSCE, the UN and the Council of Europe, and the Crimean Tatars are being oppressed. We in Europe need to understand that Russia will stop only when it is stopped. Europe is strong, Europe is capable and Europe has the power to stop any repetition of Stalinist or Nazi German purges.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the seven motions for resolutions on the Philippines - the case of Senator Leila M. De Lima

name: Anders Primdahl VISTISEN
text: poses.- Sir.Chairman!Today's debate on the situation in the Philippines goes on two legs: on the one hand, there is no doubt that every country has the right to defend itself against crime and drug gangs.On the other hand, there is no doubt that we in the European Union expect a democracy such as the Philippines to conduct the fight against crime in a proportionate manner that respects international legal guarantees.That is why it is worrying that, on the one hand, we are seeing the Philippine police use what are, from the outside, very excessive means of force in the fight against drug crime.In this context, it is important that there is full democratic oversight of whether those means of force go too far, just as the arrest and trial of Senator Lima also goes very far, and we should do everything we can to guarantee thatthe trial is fair and that the senator has all the legal guarantees intact when the trial comes before a court.

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: Author. - Mister President! In September last year, we referred to the deteriorating human rights situation in a resolution on the Philippines. President Duterte's deadly battle on drugs since his inauguration less than a year ago has claimed the lives of an estimated 7,500. We call on the Philippine government to stop this killing immediately. It must be ensured that the police and the newly deployed military comply with international legal standards in their operations. And even today the demand remains that not only extrajudicial executions, but also torture and the disappearance of persons should be investigated immediately and independently and those responsible should be brought before civil courts. Critics of President Duterte's policies must be safe from arbitrary arrests and convictions. In 2007, an important step for the country and the region, the Philippines abolished the death penalty. Now, the bill to reinstate the death penalty has only just been approved by the House of Representatives. I appeal to the Filipino government to urgently refrain from reintroducing the death penalty, not least because it has been shown to have no greater deterrent effect than other penalties. I would like to end by calling for Senator Leila de Lima to be released immediately, all charges against her to be dropped and her safety to be guaranteed in custody.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: author. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it has not been long since the last resolution on the current alarming situation in the Philippines and, unfortunately, no progress has been made. The war on drugs by President Duterte has caused more than 7 500 casualties among the civilian population. The government acted with impunity and indiscriminate, killing virtually anyone. In fact, among the victims there are not only drug traffickers but also children and innocent people. The effects of this ruthless campaign are destroying entire families: from a war on drugs it has turned into a real civil war, with the only difference that the people watch this massacre helpless and terrified and have no way of reacting. Now, under the guise of the war on drugs, the government is also trying to silence critics and opponents of the regime. Lastly, the story of Senator Leila de Lima, who had openly declared through words and deeds her dissent about the repressive and criminal policy carried out by the president since the time when he was not yet and was the mayor of the city of Davao . I expect a strong reaction, this time, from the European Union, because we cannot really afford to continue to witness this extermination.

name: Soraya POST
text: Author.- Mr President!Colleagues, President Duterte of the Philippines has emerged as a leading human rights criminal.Drug addicts are publicly humiliated.Extrajudicial executions have become commonplace, and it is not just criminals who are cleared out of the way.Recently, environmental activist Mia Mascariñas-Green was murdered in the car in front of her three children.Duterte's war on drugs is in fact a war on democracy, and now he has turned his weapons against a member of the opposition.Senator Leila M. de Lima, as one of the few politicians in the Philippines, has dared to oppose Duterte's brutality.She is now charged with drug offenses.The evidence is obviously fabricated.Mr Duterte, this madness must end.I would urge the immediate release of Senator Leila M. de Lima.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: author. - Mr President, indeed, the situation continues to deteriorate in the Philippines. President Duterte's war on drugs since coming to power in June 2016 has left more than 7,000 dead, mostly in poor neighborhoods, by both police and armed militias. Mr. Duterte wants to apply, on behalf of the state, the methods that were his when he was mayor of Davao and that Ms. de Lima rightly denounced. Successively President of the National Human Rights Commission, Minister of Justice, President of the Justice and Human Rights Committee of the Senate, Ms. de Lima tirelessly denounces corruption and extrajudicial killings. She has just been arrested, presumably on the basis of a fabricated case file. Human rights defenders, journalists in particular, are at the very least the object of threats of intimidation. President Duterte even openly threatened some of them with death. So yes, it is time to act. Yes, Ms. de Lima must be released, protected, that she has, at a minimum, the right to a fair trial, just as the plan to restore the death penalty should be denounced. The Union has the means to do this. It’s about time she did it, especially using the SPG + preferences.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: author. – Mr President, it is very disappointing to stand here discussing the human rights situation in the Philippines again so soon. Just six months ago, we passed a resolution to express our serious concern at the violent crackdown by President Duterte on the users and sellers of narcotics. Today, this policy continues to claim the lives of thousands through extrajudicial killings, with more than 60% of deaths carried out by unknown assassins and under complete impunity. Senator Leila De Lima has been a strong voice, raising legitimate concerns over the legality, humanity and actual effectiveness of such a brutal policy. De Lima is now being punished for simply condemning Duterte’s war on drugs and attempting to legally investigate killings, in accordance with the rule of law. Freedom of speech and political opposition are critical to the functioning of any democracy. The government must therefore drop its charges against Leila De Lima and guarantee her protection from any further harassment. Moreover, I call on the government of the Philippines to put an immediate end to the wave of extrajudicial executions taking place, and to condemn and investigate the actions of vigilante groups carrying out these killings. The illegal drug trade in the Philippines is a serious problem that needs to be addressed, but encouraging and condoning murder is not a solution. No matter how serious an issue may be, no government can permit violations of human rights and the rule of law to achieve an outcome. While condemning these actions, the EU should also seek to assist the government to uphold its human rights obligations.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Author.- Mr President, the case of opposition Senator Leila De Lima is an alarming example of the suppression of the rights of Philippine citizens.According to the European People's Party, it is completely unacceptable for a human rights activist who warned of the negative consequences of President Duterte's drug campaign to be arrested for drug trafficking herself.I consider this absolutely inadmissible.The arrests were based on fabricated allegations and a worsening political and social situation in the Philippines.In addition, the right to life is under increasing threat due to the recently passed law, which allows the death penalty for serious drug-related crimes.The European Union must intervene and urge the Philippine authorities to release Ms De Lima and to stop falsely accusing citizens who have rightly criticized local government practices.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: on behalf of the PPE Group.- Mr Chairman!There is no doubt that drugs pose a threat to society, and fighting them is important and necessary.Unfortunately, however, in the Philippines, action with a good general purpose has taken a very bad form of implementation.First, the allegations of illegal drug trafficking against Senator De Lima are completely fabricated and may be part of a political fight rather than the fight against drug trafficking.Second, the form that President Duterte declared in the war on drugs is highly disturbing.In just a few months, more than 7,000 people have died at the hands of the police or self-appointed lynching groups in the fight against drugs.Therefore, I believe that the European Union should use all the instruments at its disposal to influence the Philippine authorities to end these highly undemocratic practices and to respect human rights.

name: David MARTIN
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, since coming to power almost nine months ago, President Duterte has proved himself an impulsive and brutal leader. This resolution focuses on the politically motivated arrest of an outspoken critic of the President, but her situation is only a small part of the escalating instability and the climate of fear in the Philippines, motivated by the President’s policies. Senator De Lima’s arrest signals that the President is willing to take personal political feuds to the highest level. It also raises serious concerns for other opposition politicians and activists in the country. Let us be clear about this: this is not a war on drugs. This is a war on the urban poor; this is a war, as my colleague said, on democracy; and this is a war on human rights. Drugs are being used as the justification, but they are not the motivation. We must work with all our partners and all those who support due process and democracy in the Philippines to convince Mr Duterte’s government to stop the re-establishment of the death penalty, to review the minimum age of criminal liability, and to end these extrajudicial killings and political persecution. The Philippines is an important player in the region. It needs stability and democracy, and we should be supporting it in that. I was proud, two years ago, to back the re-granting of GSP+ to the Philippines, but frankly, if the human rights situation in the country does not improve, we should take the logical course, which is to say: GSP+ is granted on condition of accepting certain human rights and other labour rights, and if these are not respected, GSP+ has to be removed.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, since Duterte took office as president on 30 June 2016, his war on drugs has begun and there have been as many as 7 000 killings by the police or by paramilitary vigilantes. A brutal campaign, which will continue until 2022, in which drug users or small fish are really affected while the drug traffickers remain untouchable. The new victim is Senator de Lima, a senator who has always dealt with justice and human rights - she is the president of the commission on the subject - who was arrested on drug-related charges. As it happens, the same senator was the author of an investigation into the extrajudicial killing of more than a thousand people in Davao, a city of which Duterte was mayor for a long time. With the most classic of methods an uncomfortable character has been removed from the political scene and the worst is yet to come. On March 7, the House of Representatives passed a law to restore the death penalty for serious drug crimes and there is no doubt that it will pass. To the provocations of a president who compared himself to Hitler, who showed the middle finger to the EU and who instigates the killing of drug users and who jokes about rape and murder, we must respond firmly. So we must immediately suspend GS + preferences for the country and we must demand that Senator de Lima be released and protected because she is innocent.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: - Mr. President, in September 2016, we were already concerned about the situation in the Philippines and the behavior of President Rodrigo Duterte in his mission to eradicate the scourge of drugs in his country. If we can understand and share his desire to fight drugs, even if sometimes it can be seen as a pretext, we cannot however admit and we must denounce the manner employed by the president, who has already caused the death of more than 7,000 people. This relentlessness leads him to be guilty of the worst. The arrest of his opponent, Senator Leila De Lima, shows how ready he is to do anything to achieve his goals. It is essential that we do everything possible so that the latter can be released and that she is no longer subject to the serious accusations with which she is accused, probably the result of a file assembled from scratch, as reminded my colleague Mrs Vergiat. I am also particularly concerned about the president's wish to see the reinstatement of the death penalty. This had been abolished in 1987, to be reinstated in 1994, then abolished again in 2006. President Duterte wishes to reinstate it initially for crimes linked to drug trafficking, he says, but his final project is to extend it to other crimes afterwards.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Mr President, I would like to take part in the speeches of my colleagues who have made it clear that the fight against drugs is taking place outside the law, outside the law, in the Philippines.As a person dealing with the death penalty in the world, I am very reluctant and concerned about the growing number of executions around the world, and I also want to condemn the decision of the Philippine Parliament, the House of Representatives, which has already spoken out in favor of reintroducing the death penalty.I consider this decision to be a great mistake of the Philippine Parliament, I consider it a bad decision, a step backwards, to put this inhuman, cruel punishment back into practice.Unfortunately, it fits into the bad criminal policy of the local president.The European Union is fighting the death penalty all over the world, which is why we should condemn this parliamentary decision and clearly call on the Philippine Parliament to reconsider its decision.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: - Mr President, indeed, it is common knowledge that Senator De Lima is leading a fierce fight for the protection of human rights. President Rodrigo Duterte has paid the price on several occasions, as he has been repeatedly targeted by the senator for possible human rights violations. It would appear today that he is trying everything he can to discredit the senator. Not too long ago, he said he would destroy her publicly. Moreover, in the current situation, the use of testimony from criminals still in prison as the main basis for such charges is highly questionable. These outrageous maneuvers must be strongly condemned. Justice must defend the values ​​that are ours and those of the senator are entitled to our absolute respect, in the Philippines as elsewhere in the world. It is therefore a fair trial that is necessary in favor of the senator. Whatever the subjects, force, be it that of governments, can in no way substitute for justice in a democracy.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Mr President, the issues of tackling crime and, of course, the scourge of drugs are clearly the responsibility of the Member States, and the States themselves are responsible for tackling the issue. But of course the prosecution must respect the rule of law and the principle of proportionality. Certainly what we are seeing in the Philippines is that the scourge of drugs is being used as an alibi to clear the Philippine leadership of accounts to its political opponents, and that is the key element we are discussing today. Another issue I have not heard about is what will happen to labor rights in the Philippines, where there are thousands of working children, there is a lack of respect for labor rights, and all this is done in order for the various multinationals to benefit from exploitation of the people of the Philippines.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, ar dtús, amárach Lá Fhéile Pádraig, lá náisiúnta na nGael. Dá bhrí sin, ba mhaith liom lá ceiliúrtha maith agus sona a ghuí ar gach uile dhuine a bhfuil bá aige lenár dtír. Maidir leis an ábhar seo, tá sé de cheart ag gach uile thír troid i gcoinne drugaí mídhleathacha agus na dtiarnaí drugaí a bhíonn á reáchtáil. Ach is léir go bhfuil an tUachtarán Duterte ag dul thar fóir ar fad. Maraíodh níos mó ná 7 míle duine (dúnmharfóirí anaithnide ba chúis le 60% díobh) agus caithfimid a bheith amhrasach faoi seo agus é a cháineadh. Freisin, tá sé á úsáid chun teacht anuas ar an lucht freasúra mar a dúradh faoin Seanadóir Leila De Lima. Níl sé seo ceart agus caithfimid brú a chur ar na Filipínigh gan dul mar seo maidir leis an lucht freasúra. Caithfimid brú a chur orthu deireadh a chur le pionós an bháis agus cothrom na Féinne a thabairt don lucht freasúra. Go raibh maith agat, a Uachtaráin.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Mr President, drug-related crimes are an evil scourge on society, preying on the weak and causing untold misery and suffering. They should, of course, be treated with appropriate gravity; but there are legal, legitimate means of fighting a war on drugs, and there are illegal, illegitimate ones. What Duterte is doing now, through extrajudicial killings, is absolutely wrong, and we must surely all condemn it. How can the world trust that government to give a fair trial to Senator De Lima when it tramples upon due process and judicial proceedings? In western societies we often take for granted fundamental freedoms like the presumption of innocence, habeas corpus and the right to a fair trial. These are sadly being eroded by the Duterte regime. There is a huge difference between bringing true criminals to justice and what amounts to vigilante mob rule.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, I believe and hope that we all want to combat drug use.But not like this.The war on drugs in the Philippines is being waged out of court.Using alleged drugs to kill seems inhuman to me.Senator Leila's case is clearly part of a brutal campaign against those who criticize the Philippine system.The Philippines is a negative example of extrajudicial killing and we must support the application of human rights.We must do everything we can as a European Parliament to release the senator and to combat any attack on human rights.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, honourable Members, thank you for this resolution that draws attention to the arrest of Senator De Lima, former Secretary of Justice, former Chair of the Human Rights Commission to the Philippines and, as has been underlined, one of the most outspoken critics of the so-called war on drugs.  The EU has called on the Philippines to respect its obligations under international and domestic law, in particular to ensure the respect for the rule of law and human rights. This includes the right to due process, the independence of the judiciary, and a fair trial for all citizens. The proceedings in the case of Senator De Lima will be followed closely by the public, both in the Philippines and internationally. The EU will continue to underline the importance of the freedom of expression and opinion. As regards the wider human rights situation in the Philippines, the EU and Member States, in various meetings both in Brussels and Manila, have conveyed their significant concerns on the legality of the killings in the so-called war on drugs. We have underlined the need for effective investigations of all killings, due process and access to remedies in this respect, and our concerns on the proposal to reintroduce the death penalty and on the proposal to lower the minimum age for criminal responsibility. We have called for the protection of human rights defenders, and underlined the importance of the freedom of expression and the freedom of opinion. The EU set out these concerns in its statement to the UN Human Rights Council earlier this week. The EU and Member States will remain engaged with the Philippines on all of these issues.  At the same time, as has been recognised, we will also continue to assist the Philippine Government in their efforts on the peace process, the economy and poverty reduction. Further to a request by the Department of Health, the EU is prepared to continue to provide assistance in support of a holistic approach to drugs policy. Under the Multiannual Indicative Programme, the strengthening of the rule of law through legal and judicial reform is one of two key sectors. In particular, the EU Governance in Justice Programme includes activities related to criminal justice and contributes to strengthening the capacity of the Human Rights Commission of the Philippines.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: in writing.- As part of the debate on human rights violations in the world, which is on the agenda of every plenary session, we have addressed the Philippines today, specifically the case of Senator Leila M. De Lima of the opposition Liberal Party.She is accused of drug-related crimes.According to various NGOs, including Amnesty International, there are serious concerns that the whole case is completely fabricated, that the evidence was falsified only to gradually eliminate opposition to the government.In the resolution, we call for the safety of the senator in custody, for her immediate release and for a fair investigation of the whole case.

name: António MARINHO E PINTO
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today 39 years pass on the date on which the Italian politician Aldo Moro was kidnapped in Rome by a group of extreme left, called Red Brigades. Moro ended up being murdered in cold blood by his kidnappers about two months later, more specifically on May 9, 1978. Aldo Moro's death was due to the confluence of two factors: the bloodthirsty fanaticism of his kidnappers and the inhuman intransigence of Italian government, which refused to heed the pleas of Aldo Moro's family and Aldo Moro himself to release leaders of the Red Brigades who were in prison. The question I want to share with you today, in the European Parliament, with you, my dear colleagues, is whether the intransigence of the Italian Government was worthwhile. We have all done the legal or judicial, political and moral judgment of the material perpetrators of the crime, but Aldo Moro's murderers were tried, convicted and eventually returned to freedom. Today, everyone is at liberty, but no one has restored Aldo Moro a life. Therefore, when new fanaticisms and other intransigences are glimpsed on the European horizon, the question I leave you with is: was Aldo Moro's sacrifice worth it?

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: Thank you very much.There is another request, but my request would be to be able to vote, not to open a debate on this issue.It was very good that our colleague reminded us of this moment and we take note of it, but I would ask you to move on to the other issues on the agenda.

name: Olaf STUGER
text: - This morning, the Minister of Foreign Affairs of Turkey responded to the election results in the Netherlands.And he has made the following appeal, and I quote “Turkey wants a holy war in Europe soon after the election results in the Netherlands”, I repeat “a holy war in Europe”.The Minister of Foreign Affairs of Turkey is calling for this.I would like to know how you will respond to this.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: I am convinced that this statement has been noted by the European authorities and I am also convinced that it will receive the answer it deserves.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: This morning, the Conference of Presidents approved a request from the Commission of Inquiry into money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion for a three-month extension.The extension is necessary to enable the Commission to fully and properly implement its mandate, as adopted by Parliament on 8 June 2016, taking into account the number of documents still to be examined, the analyzes commissioned and the parties.involved to be heard.Are there any objections to extending the term by another three months?Not.In this way, we consider the extension of the mandate as approved.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item on the agenda is voting.(For results and other details of vote: see Minutes)

name: David COBURN
text: – Mr President, 14(2) RCV calls for an EU ban on drilling in ‘icy’ waters. Well, that is the sloppiest piece of legislation or proposed legislation that I have ever heard. How can you talk about ‘icy’ waters? I had my APA look it up, and all he could find was ice in whisky, or ice in Signore Tajani’s martini. How can this describe drilling? It is ridiculous. It is ludicrous.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: Mr Coburn, as far as I know, only the scotch is on the rocks, whisky is not, but apart from that I am sure that this debate has already taken place. I am sure that if there were some discussions, they have taken place there. So under the circumstances, I would suggest that we move on with the vote.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: Voting is over.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: - Mr President, I would like to ask Mr Verhofstadt, who is celebrating the very good result in the Netherlands, to go out and, rather than celebrating here, celebrate outside.Mr. President, first of all, I would like to make it clear that today in the world we still have, almost everywhere, even in the European Union, unfortunately, human rights violations.Of course, this is exactly what the United Nations needs to take very seriously, especially in those parts of the world where human rights violations are almost genocide or are indeed genocide, as the Islamic State does, for example.However, freedom of the media, freedom of association, equality of women and men, children's rights, the rights of various linguistic and religious minorities are threatened almost everywhere in the world, even in some European countries.Especially for those countries that are not members of the European Union, we know that not everything is ideal.In this context, I would like to express my strong support and that is why I voted very clearly for this report.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Mr President, I voted against the report. The bilingualism of the European Commission in relation to the protection of human rights in the European Union is obvious. In Greece, the troika and the memoranda have led 3,885,000 Greeks to live below the poverty line, while the armies of the unemployed are a disgrace to the so-called European social model. Democracy, the rule of law and human rights are violated in Greece, as I have repeatedly stated. The failed prescription of the memorandum, which has been implemented for 7 years in Greece, led 40% of the population to live below the poverty line, filling the country with armies of unemployed people, amounting to 1.5 million. As if that were not enough, the troika continues "business as usual", with the Greek government having lost the ball at the level of negotiations, trumpeting a Spanish retreat, resulting in new tough measures, which will lead to the dissolution of the Greek economy . This situation must end at last. The Greek people no longer tolerate the memoranda, which is why I voted against the report.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, I would like mainly to refer to gender equality and women’s rights, which are fundamental human rights. We must, therefore, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health and rights, condemning the global gag rule and calling on the Commission and Member States to counter its impact by increasing SSRI HR funding and launching an international fund to enhance women’s economic empowerment, by overcoming barriers in the labour market, and by giving women an equal share in all levels of decision-making. Moreover, we must involve social partners and women’s organisations in decision—making, address the needs of the most marginalised women, and highlight women as important economic agents whose participation in the labour market can stimulate the economy. Finally, we should support the establishment of an ILO convention to address gender-based violence in the workplace. I fully support this report and I believe we must translate these commitments into expenditure and make them more visible as soon as possible.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Mr President, I supported this report, which amends a proposal for a regulation which, in principle, contains some form of self-certification or self-regulation by importers of minerals from countries where civil wars are taking place or where the environment is being significantly damaged.I think that the system is very good, because it is firstly built on voluntariness, it is not a bureaucratic burden that restricts the importers themselves, and it is based on the principle that importers, like companies that are often based in the EU, should haveinterest not only in profits but also in the morale of their operations, and therefore it is very good that the regulation contains a so-called list of responsible importers, who will be able to clearly say that they are on this list and that their business does not only bear aspects of economic, but also moral aspects.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, thanks to our efforts, we have made sure that products sold in the EU do not fuel armed militias or foster human rights violations in conflict areas. We have also responded to public and consumer pressure. Consumers want to be sure that the everyday items they buy are not fuelling armed conflict and human rights abuses. Through tough negotiations and with the support of European civil society, we have ensured that the vast majority of minerals and metals imported in the EU will be covered by the regulation, cutting off a vital source of income for warlords whilst not imposing additional burdens on new small businesses.  Although this agreement is a huge step forward, there is still a long way to go to fully clean up global supply chains. We must remain committed to raising global standards and must monitor implementation efficiently to make sure it contributes to the goal of breaking the link between armed conflict and the trade in minerals and to avoid potential circumventions of the regulation.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, along with my group, I welcomed this report as it calls for mandatory due diligence checks on suppliers of tin, tantalum, tungsten and gold, otherwise known as conflict minerals. All industry initiatives now have to comply fully with international OECD due diligence guidelines. This sends out a clear message from the European Union that we wish to eliminate the strong interrelationship between trade and conflict that has defined this industry for far too long now. In the long term, regulations such as this prevent armed revolts or human rights violations being financed by the illegal revenue from mineral extraction and trade. The rapporteur’s aim was to create an efficient and workable regulation which also affords due consideration for smaller SMEs. I am confident that we have reached an agreeable solution in this regard. Looking forward, cooperation in this area will thus bolster the market in responsibly traded minerals, while serving the interests of communities and people caught in war and conflict.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, the Union framework for the collection, management and use of data in the fisheries sector and support for scientific advice regarding the common fisheries policy is a very important subject. I welcome this proposal, which introduces significant changes to the process and updates the framework for gathering and managing fisheries data in the European Union. The new rules will align this framework with the requirements of the reformed CFP and simplify the existing system.  It is important to give particular importance to the collection and transmission of data so that fisheries management can be based on the best available scientific knowledge. Moreover, it is vital that clear, reliable and accurate data be collected on fleets and their fishing activities, environmental impact and discards, in line with proper standardised statistical principles. Therefore, I welcome the proposal to amend this procedure for establishing the EU multiannual programme and its content, the functioning of the Regional Co-ordination Groups and the procedure for making data available to end-users.

name: Seán KELLY
text: –  Mr President, I support this proposal, sharing the rapporteur’s belief that the 2013 reform of the common fisheries policy (CFP) needs to be matched by adaptations in the supporting scientific advice and therefore the data needed for it. The proposed changes comply with what is necessary and appropriate for the achievement of the basic objective of improving data quality, access and availability in the fisheries sector. Quality data collection is essential for the proper implementation of the CFP. From an Irish perspective, fishing has always been economically and socially important to us as an isolated nation. With the CFP, crucial for the prevention of over-fishing and marine pollution, it is therefore important that we improve upon the functioning of the system in place. This agreement will ensure the simplification of the current data collection system, avoiding duplication and improving the framework for gathering quality data.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: - Mr. President, the Lisbon Treaty allows us what is obviously most important today: to have power, to have strength, to have military strength, to have a strong security intelligence system.This is what the European Union needs today if it wants to be a credible partner, if it wants to be credible on a global scale.It is evident in many hotspots, especially in the Middle East, that only those who have military strength can play a serious role.And what happens to us, to us who do not have military strength?We have a crisis, we have a migrant crisis because of that and we cannot act, we cannot act well.Therefore, let us use the possibilities of the Lisbon Treaty, create a strong security and intelligence union so that we can, simply put, offer our citizens more security and more seriousness for all the efforts we are all making together in this Chamber.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Mr President, security policy and foreign policy are the sole responsibility of each Member State, as set out in the Lisbon Treaty, and this must be respected by the European Union. This report lists large amounts of increase in defense spending by Member States. An increase of at least 2% of GDP in defense spending, ie around € 100 billion more by 2020, is a significant amount that could be used to increase jobs in the Union. The placement of such huge sums to support European military intervention is primarily intended to increase the profits of the European Union armaments industry and the military-industrial complex, and not in the substance of the matter, that is to say, the protection of civilians. For these reasons and for the others I mentioned in my speech yesterday, I voted against this report.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Mr President, I supported this report, I have already spoken in plenary, there are a number of positive things, such as strengthening defense money, there is an effort to strengthen defense cooperation, I mean the EU.But I want to say here, which is why I have signed up to the vote to explain that there are certain parts to which I am relatively skeptical and in which I perceive some possible tension against NATO, which I consider a key defense alliance within the European continent and Euro-Atlantic ties.In short and well, we should further debate how much we want to create a European armed force, what they will look like and how compatible they will be or how competitive they will be with NATO.If it were the latter, competition with NATO, I would have a big problem with that, and I could hardly support this project in this part in the future.

name: Diane DODDS
text: – Mr President, as we near the anniversary of the horrific terror attacks in Brussels, my thoughts and prayers go out to the families of the victims of such awful terror. We in Northern Ireland are no strangers to the legacy of the pain and loss left by ruthless terrorist gangs. Our message to you is clear: we must never allow those who perpetrated terror to rewrite the narrative of the past. It is wrong that those who now serve in this Chamber should try to glorify their deadly deeds and rewrite the narrative of the past, yet not be held accountable. This will not prevent new generations of young people from being radicalised, a point that I stressed to Commissioner King earlier this week. I also made it clear that Northern Ireland and the United Kingdom as a whole remains committed to working with the European Union to secure a safe and prosperous future for all our people. This should be a key priority in the Brexit negotiations.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Mr President, I supported this report because I generally support the creation of a defense union, and I admit that, for this reason, I do not mind a significant strengthening of this particular budget chapter.I think that the Union should focus on defense policy, on security policy, because that is exactly what citizens expect from the Union to ensure their basic security.And in my opinion, this is not about diluting cooperation with NATO.I am convinced that the challenges facing Europe, whether it is a hybrid war waged by Russia or whether it is a mass movement of people, are precisely the challenges that are so-called suitable for creating a really strong and dominant defense and security policy.Union.It is essential that this policy be coordinated with the Member States of the Union.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: - Mr President, I am voting against this text because its objective is to know how to get around the obligation to pass to a treaty which all Europeans would be seized with, before entering into this absurdity of Europe of war that you are preparing. I am alarmed by the binary vision contained in this text which opposes, for unknown reasons, a so-called "Asian" zone to a "Euro-Atlantic" zone. I'm worried that you have already set up a military staff, especially since the report claims to prepare us for high-intensity conflicts, that is, for war, no more or less. Likewise, he calls for strengthening NATO networks. I believe that you are totally beside what the European project, which is a project for peace, should be. You should ask yourself how Europe can be more effective for peace in the world, rather than asking yourself how it will contribute to the generalization of wars and to the outbreak, everywhere, of hostilities that Europe owes to all costs prevent.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: - Mr. President, Montenegro is a leader among the countries of the Western Balkans in its integration towards the European Union and NATO.However, that progress and integration process is being seriously hampered by Russia.We have seen Russian interference in domestic politics during the last election.We have seen inappropriate support for the opposition during the protests, and it is claimed that Russia also has ties to people who tried to assassinate the Montenegrin leadership.The European Union must send a clear message that Russia's political games in the Western Balkans are unacceptable.Russia's influence and manipulation must be stopped.We must not be passive observers of this because we will pay a much higher price when it is too late to fix it.The openness of this European Union to the new members from the Balkans and support for this process is the best way to calm the Balkans and Russia move away from the Balkans.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Mr President, I supported this report because I support the rapprochement of the countries of the Western Balkans, and Montenegro in particular, with the EU and support their future accession to the EU.I am very pleased that the report we voted on condemns Russia's efforts to interfere in the national situations of these countries in the Balkans.Specifically, it addresses the issue of Montenegro.I believe that after Montenegro joins NATO and the EU continues to move, the pressure from Russia may continue to increase, and we will have to be able to respond to that.The report also contains a number of things that I agree with, and analyzes the various chapters of Montenegro's rapprochement with the EU.I particularly welcome the issues relating to justice in Montenegro, which describes in great detail what needs to be improved in order for Montenegro to become a rule of law in the future and thus have the same parameters of justice as the EU Member States.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: - Mr. President, I supported this report because I am one hundred percent convinced that the approach and entry of Montenegro into the European Union one day, not too far from today, is something that will contribute to stabilization in the Western Balkans.Montenegro plays a very positive role.The pro-European leadership that is leading Montenegro today also talks about how it wants to change its state, it wants to reform Montenegro.We see that many chapters are open.We expect new chapters to open.We expect that the government will really tackle everything that is important for the citizens of Montenegro, and I believe that the fact that this small country in the Western Balkans cooperates well with its neighbors will contribute to them, its neighbors, Montenegrin neighbors, being a step forward.closer to the European Union when it becomes the first member from the Western Balkans, a new member of the European Union.

name: Diane JAMES
text: –  Mr President, e-democracy offers the promise of enhanced democratic participation by e-consultations, but e-petitions etc. come with their own challenges. Firstly, democracy favours the younger generations, with older people often being less technically savvy, and their interests must be protected. Secondly, systems like e-petitions are prone to abuse, with algorithms being deployed to up the voting numbers, resulting in inappropriate outcomes. Thirdly, e-democracy can slow down the decision-making process by triggering debates in parliaments. Finally, e-democracy comes with the threat of hacking, identity theft and data leaks. Unless all four of these areas are solved and resolutions found I will not be able to support e-democracy in this Parliament.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Mr President, I voted in favor of the report. The involvement of citizens and civil society in the public is crucial for the proper functioning of democracy and the rule of law, as well as for the accountability of national and EU systems of representation. Of course, the attitude of the European institutions towards the economic crisis and the refugee crisis shakes the confidence of the people in these institutions, while e-democracy, which should support the principles of democracy through information technology and governance, has not succeeded until reduce the lack of public confidence. In order to restore citizens' confidence in the European institutions, the European Union must redefine its objectives, emphasizing the effective resolution of the migration crisis. Also, for the refugee to immediately implement the relocations from Greece to other countries of the European Union. Also, to face the high unemployment rates that exist in Greece and the countries of the South. At the same time, e-democracy should strengthen citizens' trust in European institutions.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - President! The use of different forms and tools of e-democracy will play an important role in our societies in the future. Internet consultations and various petitions already today indicate important issues that are of paramount importance to a particular segment of society. Nevertheless, in line with the report, it is important to emphasize the existence of the digital divide and the fact that there are social groups in each Member State that either do not have access to the Internet or the technical skills to use it. We must emphasize that, as unpopular as politics is, the mandate to settle our common affairs is still given in general elections, on the basis of the principle of representation. Therefore, in the digital space, in many cases, special attention needs to be paid to ensuring transparency so that the definition of the public interest is not jeopardized and the opinion of a stronger advocacy group with digital skills does not appear as public opinion.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: - Dear visitors of the European Parliament, the services of the e-Democracy package provide access to faster business start-ups, faster training and are also an important element of the infrastructure for the effective exchange of good practices. However, implementation requires resources in the development of digital infrastructure and human capital as teachers and learners. Investments should also be made in the development of skills in the fight against internet fraud, fake news and other forms of content abuse and manipulation. I believe that the European Union must set the tone to combat these global challenges. In the age of digital society, e-government and administration must be accessible to all, without, of course, disregarding data protection security considerations. However, I believe that citizens who have either limited access to electronic services or an inability to work with them should not be overlooked. Electronic services must be accessible, but not an exclusive form of access to information. Citizens, regardless of their age and computer literacy, are citizens and have rights, and they must be respected.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The voting period ended.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is large questions.Ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues!We have two new instruments this week, the topical debate on the one hand and the major inquiries on the other.Yesterday I had the privilege of chairing the first current debate that was introduced with the new Rules of Procedure.I am pleased to be able to manage the first major inquiry now.The author of this great question, Mr Coburn, begins for two minutes.

name: David COBURN
text: author. –  Mr President, I think this is a good innovation – more like Prime Minister’s Question Time in the House of Commons, the Mother of Parliaments, so perhaps the centre of the European democracy is following the Mother of Parliaments.  Cooperation between human traffickers and NGOs engaged in search and rescue in the Mediterranean.  On 15 December 2016, the Financial Times, which I am sure you all know, published several excerpts from leaked Frontex reports that suggest a high level of cooperation between smugglers and NGOs: - ‘…criminal networks were smuggling migrants directly on an NGO vessel’; - ‘…clear indications before departure on the precise direction to be followed in order to reach the NGO boats’ - ‘…people rescued by NGO vessels were often “not willing to cooperate with debriefing experts at all, with some claiming that they were warned not to cooperate with Italian law enforcement or Frontex”.’  This period has also witnessed a surge in NGO activity in the region and a sharp drop in rescues in response to distress signals. Frontex suggested the latter is due to ‘NGOs cooperating closer to Libyan territorial waters’ or even the lights used by rescue boats, which the agency said acted ‘as a beam for the migrants’.  Does the Commission believe that such actions constitute cooperation with the smugglers, and if not, could it define what would?  Does it believe that such actions constitute collusion, and if not would it define what would?  Does the EU provide any financial assistance to NGOs engaged in search and rescue in the Mediterranean?  Is Frontex hiding anything we should all know about, since we are paying them? I think this place should know more.

name: David COBURN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank you for the opportunity afforded by those questions to clarify one or two issues.  First, as has been reiterated in the EU action plan against migrant smuggling, the duty to render assistance to persons or vessels in distress at sea is an obligation under international law. This is a binding obligation on states, who are obliged to ask ship masters of private, commercial or military vessels to render assistance. The ship masters vessels of nongovernmental organisations are bound by the same duties as ship masters of state vessels.  Second, it does not help to make, if I may say so, general assumptions on the role of all civil society organisations. These organisations are mostly active in support of governments and international organisations. At the same time, rules must be respected, and close coordination between all involved in search and rescue operations in the Mediterranean is obviously key to ensuring the safety of all concerned, migrants and crews alike.  Coordination of the rescue efforts is ensured primarily by the state responsible for the region where an incident is taking place. Any assisting vessel, be it private owned or state controlled, must therefore follow the instructions of the responsible Maritime Rescue Coordination Centre. So to take this example, in the case of search and rescue in the central Mediterranean region, coordination must take place with the Italian authorities.  Third, when it comes to criminalisation of migrant smuggling, we need to be clear about the existing legal framework. According to existing EU legislation, facilitation of unauthorised entry is the act of intentionally assisting a person who is not a national of a Member State to enter or transit across the territory of a Member State in breach of that Member State’s immigration laws. National authorities are the competent body to judge this. They are also competent to assess whether the conduct of any NGO, or indeed other legal or natural person, rescuing people in a specific case could amount to a form of collusion or cooperation with migrant smuggling networks.  So far the Commission has not received any official information from any Member States about investigations or prosecutions of NGOs involved in search and rescue activities in the Mediterranean for having participated in migrant smuggling.  Finally I would like to emphasise that the Commission does not provide any financial assistance to NGOs engaged in search and rescue activities in the Mediterranean. EU funding through the International Security Fund can support search and rescue operations at sea which arise during maritime border surveillance operations. These are the exclusive responsibility of public authorities, hence search and rescue operations carried out by third parties, such as NGOs, are not eligible under the Internal Security Fund for EU funding.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: for the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, I have listened very carefully to your answer to the questions that have been raised here. Personally, the answers did not completely satisfy me, they were very general. I believe that if there have been some statements or leaks of information from Frontex in the media, then the Commission should examine this more and look more at how relevant the agency's information is or whether it is just some of the contextual theses and they are basically untrue, they are only misaligned. I am a supporter of the non-profit sector, I consider their activities important. On the other hand, if there is a suspicion that some non-profits, even if unknowingly, are helping smugglers, then this is very important information and should not end with just such a general statement. So please, it would be good to go into this more, to hear the representative of Frontex and possibly inform Parliament in some more detail. I am convinced that these problems, which are described here and also described in the media, are due to the fact that we are still failing what we often talk about, to set up some refugee camps in North Africa where these people could be. temporarily collected and from where their possible asylum procedure in relation to individual EU countries could be addressed. Until this succeeds, there is a risk that the number of refugees from Africa will increase in the future, and there is also a risk that tragedies at sea will unfortunately not fall sharply. So, in my opinion, today's debate is only a fragment of the whole problem, and the European Commission should focus more on whether it is possible to set up camps in Africa in the future, where potential asylum seekers would be located and from there asylum. they asked.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr President, the issue we are discussing is very serious. I have visited the Aegean islands and I have a complete picture of what is happening. I have visited Samos four times, Lesvos twice, Eidomeni once and Chios once. So I have a picture of what is happening, and right now there are several thousand refugees trapped in the Aegean islands, but mostly illegal immigrants; that is the key. This is the dominant element in the Aegean islands today and, Commissioner, the deportations must begin. This situation can not remain. Secondly, from the first moment I have officially complained that NGOs are a state within a state. They do whatever they want at the level of Greece. They have no control, nor do they have control by the Commission. In Chios they have created an improvised hospitality area inside the archeological site. If this had been done by a Greek citizen he would have been arrested. What matters is what the funds become. That's the key! 195 million euros have been given by the European Union to NGOs and they are having a party. The refugees thawed in Moria, in Ritsona. There is a problem with the food they give, the supplies they make, the conditions under which they make them, or the amounts they give to the so-called volunteers, which are incredible. No control! What I tell you I have said here before. I have intervened and I have asked, Mr President, for OLAF to intervene, for a final audit. I had told Mr. Stylianidis - he was sitting there - that there would be a problem. So I think first of all the funds should go to the local government, where there is control, where there is a possibility to know what we are doing. And furthermore, Commissioner, I invite you: on 27 March, representatives from the Aegean islands will come to Brussels for an event to tell you what is happening. So significant intervention is needed, because the issue cannot continue this.The key is the funds that NGOs receive; the party that takes place.Stop this party and you will see that there will be no problem.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. - Mr. President, although I always want to be very careful when conducting political debates based on newspaper articles, no matter how serious the Financial Times is, which I have no doubt about, but I sometimes have little doubt about our friends from EFDD because they also know how to use various arguments, and especially, I have to say, some experiences with NGOs that were great, but there are also a lot of NGOs that I really had very bad experiences with. Here, however, I want to add something that I consider extremely important, and that is that Frontex itself said that criminal networks smuggled immigrants directly by ship to NGOs. That can be verified, Mr. Commissioner. It can be checked which NGOs they are. Frontex is obliged to tell us information, it is obliged to tell you information. Therefore, it can be checked. Also, it is unbelievable that the migrants were not at all willing to cooperate with the people in charge of the interrogation, and some even said that they did not want to cooperate with the Italian police, that is, with Frontex. These are serious accusations. These are serious but verifiable accusations. In this context, I invite you to really try to put an end to these stories, to know exactly what happened and to finally have a common strategy for everything that is happening in the Mediterranean, because otherwise, we know it's too late, let's not be up to it. end late.

name: Julia REID
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, this important debate this afternoon on the links between human traffickers and NGOs would not have been possible if it were not for the EFDD group taking this initiative. This is an important topic and needs to be addressed, and not simply brushed under the carpet. In December last year, the Financial Times published excerpts from a leaked Frontex report that suggested there was a high level of cooperation between people smugglers and NGOs. The leaked report claimed criminal networks have been assisting migrants by giving clear indications on which direction they need to take to reach the NGO boats. Unforgivably, there have also been reported cases where migrants have been smuggled directly onto NGO vessels, so it is alleged.  It is not just criminal gangs and NGOs who are benefiting from this crisis, but also Islamic extremism. Current migration policies adopted by the EU and Chancellor Merkel have enabled terrorist organisations such as ISIS to smuggle their supporters into Europe, which has enabled them to carry out a number of attacks. Opening up Europe’s doors indiscriminately has put at risk not only the lives of migrants who make the treacherous journey, but also the lives of ordinary Europeans who now face the threat of terrorism on a daily basis.  UKIP have said from the very start of this crisis that we need to have a tough but fair policy on this crisis to stop innocent lives being lost at sea and to stop the profiteering of criminal gangs and ISIS. To date, the UK government has committed over GBP 2.3 billion to helping refugees in Syria and the region, the second largest donor, and since its inception, almost 4 500 Syrians have entered the UK under the Syrian vulnerable person resettlement programme. Perhaps the EU would do better to follow the UK’s example rather than have desperate people paying vast sums of money to smugglers who only view them as a disposable commodity.

name: Georg MAYER
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Mister President! I would like to use this topic of the “migration crisis” here again, perhaps to put the topic of Turkey in the focus of my interest after we have been accompanied by these provocations immanently in the last few days. It's terrifying what you hear - especially from the Turks - and I think this deal with Turkey is not worth the paper on which it is written - and they now know it too. It gets intense when you listen to the latest statement from the Turkish Foreign Minister today, who says: There will be religious wars. He will ensure that we experience religious wars. Of course, it is not wise to respond to every provocation by a Turkish politician with a counter-provocation. But it should not be as discouraged as one experiences on the part of the European Union or the Member States. Because I can tell you that you will only get respect from Turkey if you say at some point: this far and no further. But these are - and this is what is particularly frightening - the partners that the socialists and conservatives are bringing into the Union. The membership negotiations have only been put on hold; That would mean: We have your partners, whom you would like so much to have, then also sit here in the house. When the Turkish foreign minister talks about religious wars, that is very significant, and I think we should pay attention. Because we know that, thanks to the failed policy of Merkel and Co., millions of migrants have come to Europe, of whom we have no data, do not know their names and do not know who these people are. Mostly men - so submarines. You can see the excesses of this policy quite well when you come to Parliament. We are guarded by soldiers, the house is barricaded, we bunker. And that is the result of this policy. It is no longer an open house, as a parliament should be.That reminds me a lot of Max Frisch: The play "Biedermann und die Brandstifter" - for those who know it.Biedermann is a citizen who invites two arsonists into his house and takes care of them, although they clearly show that they want to set fire to something;At the latest - and I tell you - after the next attacks - and they will certainly come - we will probably have tanks in front of this Parliament here too, thanks to the failed policy of Red and Black.

name: Georg MAYER
text: - Mister President!That is a new point in the Rules of Procedure.I did refer to the issue of migration, and that includes, of course, the agreement with Turkey.In this respect, I think that I have not overstepped the curve, but have referred to Turkey, the refugee deal and the current processes that are taking place with Turkey and with all Member States in Europe.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: I don't want to comment on that any further.In any case, the agreement with Turkey is not an agreement with an NGO.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, an article published by the Financial Times on 15 December 2016 contained several excerpts from leaked Frontex reports and claimed a high level of cooperation between smugglers and NGOs. The newspaper has since retracted claims that Frontex had accused NGOs of collusion with smugglers. No doubt about it, but this is a very troubling accusation in an already distressing human rights situation. Rescue missions are conducted with great valour, bravery and spirit on the part of those people involved in them, whether they are the European Border and Coast Guard, Frontex, Member States or non-governmental organisations.  In this regard, I would like to sincerely sympathise with the families of Captain Dara Fitzpatrick and the crew of the Irish coastguard helicopter that tragically crashed this week, illustrating the point.
