The European response to various crises has been adopted in the spirit of solidarity and cooperation on which the European Union was founded. I would hope that this approach will continue to guide our action in this area and that we will move forward. I would like to highly commend all those who work in the sector. 5 000 people died at sea last year. From an Irish point of view I am disappointed with such claims, given the European and my own government’s commitment to relieving the humanitarian crisis as it has developed in recent years. In September 2015, as a direct response to this humanitarian crisis, the Irish Refugee Protection Programme was established. In a gesture towards the most vulnerable individuals of this migration crisis, Ireland pledged to accept the quota asked of it by the EU. I wish to take this opportunity to stress our deep commitment to delivering our decision to accept these refugees and asylum seekers. At present, more than 12 500 refugees have been rescued from Mediterranean waters by Irish naval forces. We have dispatched countless naval service vessels and our commitment to continue doing so still remains undisputed.  However, suggestions of collusion between human traffickers and NGOs provide yet another obstacle to the roll-out of Europe-wide rescue and resettlement efforts. It is thus paramount that no cloud should hang over the human rights agencies and NGOs which are entrusted in these areas.

name: James NICHOLSON
text: – Mr President, I think we can all understand to some extent and sympathise immensely with the problems that the Mediterranean area has faced, not just in recent months but over a considerable period of time. There is no doubt we can all agree and condemn those involved in human trafficking and the smugglers, and it is a serious question why some of this has been allowed to continue by some of the nation states that are involved within this area.  Well, I think Professor Marias  hit the nail on the head when he said you have to identify and distinguish between the refugees and the illegal immigrants. I think we would do well to listen to what he says because he is coming very close to what has not been taken up by many and has been misrepresented by others. So we would do well to listen.  As someone with my past and the situations I have been through, I have learned that you need to deal with the facts. Newspapers do not refuse publicity and they do not always tell us everything that is there.

name: Jozo RADOŠ
text: - Mr President, the representative of the Commission said that the Commission does not have a report from the Member States that there is such cooperation. On the other hand, the Financial Times gives very precise quotations from the Frontex report about which the Commission representative should have some knowledge. Obviously something problematic is going on. It is an example of how politics can be deformed and how a common interest has been found from completely opposite points of view, interests and motives. And if one were to ask a hypothetical question: if that cooperation saved thousands of human lives, who can be against such cooperation even if it is actually a deformation and not a policy? This question shows that the European Union cannot have an answer to the mass influx of refugees if it does not use force, or at least inhumane behavior. The real solution to dealing with the great pressure of refugees is, of course, to act in those areas where crises occur - humanitarian, economic and security. The European Union does not have comprehensive crisis management in any of these areas, and that is why we will be facing such crises for a long time to come, including the moral dilemmas that these crises and situations like this open up.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: - Mr. President, I would like to emphasize the importance of those organizations that sacrificed themselves to help people who could die, who could die.There is no doubt that many NGOs have really helped the most disadvantaged because those who want to come to Europe, the vast, vast majority, are not criminals but simply people who no longer know what and how in life and want to come to Europe that seems like onea wonderful fairy tale.But there is an additional problem, the problem of smuggling and the problem of the arrival of migrants will not disappear.On the contrary, it will be constantly present, perhaps even bigger.That is why our engagement must be lasting around everything, and to my esteemed, dear Austrian friend, I will not say it in my mother tongue, German, but I will only tell him that he received the answer to his discussion last night in the elections in the Netherlands.That is the answer to what you said, dear Mr. Mayer.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, there are a number of serious points that have been raised. We take them seriously. I will discuss them with responsible colleagues and indeed with the heads of relevant agencies.  Can I just repeat that saving lives at sea is a priority and indeed an obligation under international law, and that remains the case, including during the current migration crisis. I would like to associate myself with the comments made by Mr Kelly about the devotion of those involved in saving lives at sea, some of whom pay a very high price for that work. I, on behalf of the Commission, condemn unreservedly those involved in human trafficking and those who seek to profit from migration smuggling.  Successfully addressing the migration crisis is going to depend on the active cooperation of all of us, all parts of state authorities and civil society including NGOs. In the end, as I said earlier, national authorities are competent to assess if the conduct of an NGO constitutes a criminal offence based on the applicable national, EU and international law.  Just to be clear on funding, as was asked, the Commission does not provide funding to NGOs or other non-governmental actors to carry out search and rescue activities.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: written. - It is disappointing that the Commission not only did not reply to our big question on time, it also completely refrained from answering it. The big question is an important minority instrument, especially for the opposition factions, who refuse to reach a general consensus here in this House. The Commission continues to show no responsibility towards the EU Parliament. It sees itself as a floating government. She looks like an absolutist prince who has been appointed to our time. However, we have overcome the age of absolutism. Governments owe parliaments to answer questions. But the Commission doesn't care. She does her thing, unimpressed by what is happening here in Parliament. This can be seen in the handling of the large request, and it shows in the listless, sometimes cheeky and empty answering of our inquiries for written answers. And I tell you, Commissioner, if you go on like this, it will also be the end of the Commission as we have it today. Because no sovereign can put up with such high-handed hustle and bustle in the long run. You know what I'm talking about because your country - Great Britain - has already left this elite club called the EU.
